Hellish light puzzler with amazing graphics.

There isn't much to write about Tormentum.
It's as reduced as adventures can go. Minimal amount of dialogue, options or clutter.
Do not expect hyper complex riddles. In fact, if you sneer at women's adventures aka hidden object games, the game might be not for you. It's situated somewhere between Myst and Artifex Mundi HOGs, with a dark, beautifully painted twist.

Meaning no young witch in colourful fairy forests but a hellish wayfarer traversing Giger's version of Burning Man.

Check out the screenshots. If you'd like to spend a few hours puzzling about in these worlds, Tormentum will not disappoint.
As far as light adventures go, you got solid (again, for the genre) puzzles and above average sound effects.

There aren't lots of games with an artistic vision coming so vividly to ludic (un)life.

Tormentum - Dark Sorrow je vlastně naprosto obyčejná point-and-click adventura, která vede díky možnosti rozhodování se ve klíčových situacích k více vyústění příběhu a koncům. V čem však naprosto boduje je tísnivá atmosféra a grafická stylizace inspirovaná díly pánů Gigera či Beksiňskiho nebo hernímy světy Dark Seed a Demon's Souls, která potěší nejednoho úchyláka. Myšleno v dobrém. Hrdě se totiž k těmto úchylákům hlásím.

Nepřináší nic nového. Můžete počítat s lehkými logickými hádankami. Taky můžete počítat s tím, že se občas poperete se svou vlastní podezíravostí. Hlavní hrdina si nepamatuje ani své vlastní jméno, netuší kde je, co má za sebou, ocitá se v nejrůznějších kritických situacích a naráží na všemožné postavy, u kterých si nemůže být jistý ničím. Mám dát na první dojem? Nehraje to na mě? Nebo jsou třeba jen stejně nedůvěřiví jako já? To se stejně nejspíš dozvíte až bude pozdě.

Hra mě bavila. Bavila mě i když jsem jí věnovala další dva rychlé průchody k získání nejlepšího a nejhoršího možného konce. A i tak si myslím, že se k ní zase někdy ráda vrátím. A pokud Vás tenhle kousek zaujal stejně jako mě, doporučím vám ještě jednu hříčku. TSIOQUE měla vyjít někdy během podzimu, ale nestihla to. Snad se jí dočkám co nejdřív. Měla by nabídnout podobnou atmosféru, ale navíc i humor a roztomilost skrze dívčí hrdinku Tsioque.

Klady:
+ Amosféra

+ Hádanky
+ Postavy

38598538.review:
[b]Inspirados na estética de dois pintores fantásticos, este Point-and-Click imerge o jogador neste universo sombrio, inquietante e deslumbrantemente aterrorizador, com um mistério interessante e puzzles variados.[/b]

[h1]Estética[/h1]
Podia fazer uma análise apenas focada neste quesito, já que apenas ela já foi o suficiente para me fazer comprar Tormentum. Sempre adorei as pinturas de Zdzisław Beksiński, umas das poucas obras que me causavam sentimentos intensos de desconforto, inquietude e, acima de tudo, são lindas. Juntamente com H. R. Giger, que nunca cheguei a seguir muito seu de trabalho a fundo, mas que foi a mente criativa responsável pelo design de um dos filmes que eu mais adoro e, para mim, um dos melhores filmes de terror já feitos: Alien, o Oitavo Passageiro. O resultado de um jogo inspirado nas obras deste dois excelentes pintores não poderia ser diferente, é algo deslumbrante. Mas não no sentido literal da palavra.

Sem mostrar nada de violento ou de gore para o jogador, Tormentum consegue causar um embrulho no estômago e desconforto em diversos momentos com sua arte. A inspiração nos dois pintores é nítida e feita com perfeição pelos desenvolvedores. Algo que eu nunca havia experienciado em um jogo de videogame, com certeza. 

[h1]Progressão do jogo[/h1]
Infelizmente, todo esmero que foi colocado na hora de desenvolver a estética do jogo, não foi igualmente colocado no restante do jogo. O gênero do Point-and-Click é caracterizado pela simplicidade na jogabilidade, isto não é surpresa para ninguém, mas normalmente eles compensam em outros aspectos, geralmente, na narrativa. Em Tormentum, a história contada não é complexa e nem é um ponto alto do jogo; faz o arroz com feijão. Os puzzles não são muito criativos, o que causa um pouco de desinteresse na hora de realizados. Se a estética fosse aproveitada na hora do desenvolvimento dos puzzles, coisas bem interessantes poderiam ter saído, mas não foi o caso; posso classifica-los como OK. 


[b]Tormentum é uma obra de arte, com estética única e diferente até mesmo dos grandes jogos de terror que são lançados todos os anos. Mas é útil frisar que não é um jogo para todos. Se você busca algo com mais ação e desafios interessantes e criativos, não indicaria a compra. Mas se você assim como eu ficou interessado em conhecer a parte artística do jogo, pode ir de cabeça que não irá se desapontar. [/b]

Veredito:
Nota -
[h1]7,0[/h1]

While the art was beautiful, the puzzles were very straightforward. Items required were very obvious, and most of the puzzles were standard.

This game turned out to be a morality play. Throughout the game, you are given choices to kill bad people or allow them to live. Either option can make sense given the setting and rationale. You can be merciful to the creature, but allow them to hurt others again; or you could kill a hurtful creature, though the reasoning for it is up to you: compassion, justice, malice, etc.

At the very end though, two messages are given with a heavy hand: Suicide is always terrible and cowardly, and No creature, no matter how evil, deserves to be killed. 

Can't say I agree with the messages, so I was a bit let down by this. The game flat out tells you that it's better to let the world destroy you slowly rather than take your life. Don't agree, but to each their own.

Overall: Artwork is great. Puzzles a bit too simple. Heavy handed messages.

[b] “For if any man thinks that he is alone is wise-that in speech, or in mind, he hath no peer-such a soul, when laid open, is ever found empty.” 

― Sophocles, Antigone [/b]

Imagine reading an exceptional novel, arousing your imagination awake with its surrealness, each word twisting through your mind in an inspiration of awe. Now imagine doing so but sat outside on a capriciously icy autumn afternoon, a sensation of melancholic hollowness rising from your gut to clench your throat, fingers stung by the cruel weather and yet your famished curiosity manipulating you to once again move them in order to reach the next page.

This is what I felt as I breathlessly experienced this game's thorned beauty, its humble genius provoking me to return and make new choices until all possible outcomes were revealed. 

You are a nameless hooded stranger who finds himself in an enchantingly terrifying world to match one of Dante's circles of hell. Without giving away too many of the game's numerous macabre delights I will simply say: be prepared to fight your way to verity through a series of morality-challenging decisions and elegantly executed puzzles. The ease at which many of the game's riddles can be solved is perhaps its only downside, however I found that the unique sombreness of the tale's plot  as well as its memorableness made up for that weak point in the end.

And of course the artwork, oh the artwork! Nothing less of being the most stunning bow of respect to the work of the exceptional artist H.R. Giger whose unmistakeable style was the main inspiration for the game's design. Each new location is practically a painting in oil, with morbid grace lacing each one down to the smallest details - an excellent example alone of how much effort and love was put into its making. The design intertwines its fingers lovingly with the game's soundtrack, so delicate and solemn, so varied to match your every step it is like the aftertaste of a particularly delectable aged wine - robust and floral in its palette of tones.

I got exactly what I desired from a point-and-click game of its cost: an unforgettably woeful and painfully gorgeous tale brimming with twisted choices and macabre surrealism.

In terms of difficulty, I would say that this game is definitely on the mediocre side. The gameplay consists predominently of puzzle solving, with the occasional sprinkle of moral choices here and there. The puzzles in the game are a bit too easy – at least to my liking – so if you're looking for a challenging puzzle game, then this game is not it. The moral choices you are given are binarily simplistic, i.e. you either do "good" or "bad". I have seen some people struggle to understand the ethics of the game and feel that it is just favouring silly compassion or is too naïve, and that it does not give room for more complex moral nuances. However, as far as I could tell, these said people failed to realise that the morality of the game is essentially that of Kantian ethics, i.e. [i] your actions toward others and yourself should always be based in an honest wish for the betterment of their and your well-being [/i] – anything else is considered to be morally wrong. You might disagree with the approach to include only one ethical framework, but if you are surprised that the game considers any of your choices morally wrong, then the fault does not lie on the shoulders of the developers.

The length of the story is also a bit too short to my liking; combined with the easy puzzles, it will only take you about 4 hours to complete the game. The story itself, the one of a man who tries to find himself in a world of misery and depressiveness, is fairly well-written all considered, like a horror fairy-tale version of Alice in Wonderland. Nonetheless, it is not something that will take you by surprise as it is quite classic, almost like something from ancient Greek myths.

The atmosphere of the game, the aesthetics and the music, is definitely the stronger point of the game, but given how short the game is, it does not leave you with a long-lasting impression, which I think is regrettable. I have to say I am a fan of H. R. Giger's artstyle, and it was cool to see a universe that paid tribute to it, but it did not feel like the game tried to expand on such artstyles in its own creative way, rather one is left with the impression of an echo or shadow of something more original and imaginitive. I also think that the visuals in the game, while exquisitely macabre, lack the high resolution and high details to really send it home.

All in all, I would only recommend this game to people that are fan of a macabre artstyle and do not mind a rather classic story of misery. It is easy to just pick up and play through in one go, so it might also be interesting for people who do not want to invest hours upon hours into a game they doubt they will ever complete. Also, be aware that the game is an exercise in Kantian ethics, so do not fault the game if your understanding of its ethics is rudimentary.

34987040.review:
Ive played a few hidden object/puzzle style games such as this now, enjoying most of them rather well, but nothing Ive played has the atmosphere and style this one has.   
Tormentum is not just a hidden object, point and click adventure game.   This one is about story, morality, life and death.   To truly get the most out of this game you can't simply focus on the puzzles themselves, you have to pay attention to what you're doing, what's going on in the world, and the consequences your actions might have.  

The puzzles are not overly difficult by any means.   Really rather simple, actually, as far as these games go.  
Its not a long game, either.  An afternoon/evening is enough time to get through it all, if you take your time or get stuck for a while (as I did, trying to be lazy I missed something).  

But the art and style, the aesthetic, are superb.  The music fits the game.   The decor is incredible for setting the mood and tone.  And the game itself is just solid.    Mouse clicks are responsive, clicking on interactable objects in the game are nice and reactive, the load times are nigh instantaneous, the menu options are as you would hope.  No irritation with mouse clicks or transitioning between zones/areas/slides.  Using objects from your pack is simple, everything behaves as you would hope and expect.

This game is simply fantastic.  It has all it needs and it is all that it should be.

I think I came across this game while reading something related to the Dark Souls series. Kept it in my wishlist for a while before purchasing it in a promotion. I honestly think it was because of the dark aesthetics of Tormentum - Dark Sorrow.

I fell in love with the H.R. Giger style right away. It's haunting, it's brooding, and it does feel like you fell in a trap you can`t quite get out before a couple of hours of therapy. I know, I know, H.R. Giger has a thing for phalluses and phallic imagery, which (un)fortunately isn't delivered here. 

The story is great. You wake up a prisoner and you have to get out. Your memory is gone and you don't know who the F you are. You just have to get out. If the lines in the game didn't tell you, you'd still feel that escaping is the only viable option.

The art is stunning and the freaking ending is just a masterpiece. The choices you make are all tied up in the end, so it all makes a lot a sense.

I tend to get tired of point-and-click games that are huge story-wise, but Tormentum - Dark Sorrow hit the spot in lenght. Long enough so you have a great time figuring out the puzzles and enjoying the art, but not long where it becomes blatant. It ends right on time.

Finished the game, got the good ending.

PROS
+Artwork is unbelievable.
+The story and world feels satisfyingly vague and unfamiliar. You are a stranger in a strange land in this game and it does a great job of making you feel this way.
+Puzzles are straightforward enough to be understandable after a couple minutes of thought, but are not so simple as to feel pointless.
+Characters are interesting and have their own motives.
+Sound design is top shelf.
+The artwork is seriously fantastic, like damn.
+The game has a good and coherent flow - it's not just setpiece after setpiece but instead feels like it's naturally moving along.

CONS
-It's really, really short. Like three hours tops.
-The story's resolution was really unsatisfying. I don't want to spoil it but after several hours of world-building I was hoping for better than an "okay player, here's an explanation for everything".
-I hope you like sliding tile puzzles.

Totally worth it if you like Beksinski/Giger/etc-style surrealist-horror art, or point and click adventures. I enjoyed every minute of this game and I'm going to play it again just to see the art again.

33624088.review:
[h1]Visuals[/h1]
This game has a really unique style that I've never seen in a game before. I'm not even sure how I'd describe it but I really enjoyed looking through the smaller details as I moved from screen to screen. Honestly, the art was a massive part of why I bought this game in the first place and if you're put off by the visual style then you may want to pass on Tormentum. 

[h1]Puzzles/Gameplay[/h1]
The puzzles in this are pretty standard adventure game fare. You've all different kinds of sliding tile puzzles, a rush hour puzzle, a puzzle with tetrominos, and a handful of others. They're enough to keep you busy and engaged with the game but nothing that's going to make you think too hard.

To the developers' credit, I didn't feel like there were any puzzles that fell into the trap of "adventure game logic". The riddles and other similar puzzles were written well.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The overall story isn't anything groundbreaking but I enjoyed it for what it was. I think mentioning Demon's Souls in the game's description might be a little off though. The tone and atmosphere of the game certainly evoke the Souls series but I didn't feel that the story was similar at all.

You make some choices throughout the game that I found pretty interesting. They're nothing groundbreaking but they gave me some agency over what happened in the story and I enjoyed thinking about what to do in each situation.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
I really enjoyed the soundtrack for this game as well. The ambient music that plays as you wander around and solve the puzzles does a great job setting a mysterious and slightly creepy mood. I also really enjoyed Slippin Away by Matt Naylor that played during the credits.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
I definitely recommend Tormentum - Dark Sorrow to anyone that looks at the screenshots and wants to see more. The game took me about 2 hours and 30 minutes to finish the first time through if length is a concern for you. My second playthrough (to get the ending I missed the first time through) took about an hour.

33411606.review:
This game had been sitting on my wishlist for quite some time before I decided to take the leap and take it for a spin.  I was not disappointed!

As is immediately apparent from the screenshots and trailer, Tormentum's most notable quality is its hideously gorgeous art design.  A hybrid of H.R. Giger and Hieronymus Bosch, revealing each new area was the greatest force in motivating me forward.  The visual design is consistently excellent, and excels at creating a vibrant, absorbing and disturbing world.

How engaging the gameplay is will depend on how obtuse you like your point-and-click adventure puzzles.  Some may find its puzzles simplistic and easy, but I found it very enjoyable.  The game presents enough puzzles and riddles to keep one engaged, but doesn't make things so enigmatic as to grind the pacing of the story to a halt (no chicken-pullies or inflatable-duck-tongs-band-aid-rope things here).  

What's more, the game does a good job of allowing those "ah-ha" moments by keeping player knowledge and character knowledge in balance.  One of my greatest pet peeves in adventure games is when I've determined the solution for a puzzle, but the game won't let you progress until the character has had the solution spelled out to them via dialogue or a diagram.  Fortunately, that never occurred here.  The game moves along at a steady pace, and is very hard to put down.

Either way, you probably won't have to worry about putting this game down, as it can very feasibly be completed in a single sitting.  My playthrough took about 4 hours, which is fine for me because it means the game didn't overstay its welcome.  I didn't feel like the game was lacking in content, and believe extending the running time to a full 8 or 12 hours would have caused the setting and tone to grow tired.  In this case, each setting was consistently fresh and fascinating.

Throughout the game, there is a heavy emphasis on moral choices.  It is true that the game is monitoring the things you do, and there are two endings based on the choices you make.  This is, unfortunately, where the game stumbles.  While the choices you encounter are very clear in their binary good-vs-evil quandaries, they tend to exist in a vacuum where you are judged regardless of the larger context of the situation.  Expect to forgive and free everyone you meet if you want the good ending, even if that person is a dangerous murderer or tyrannical overlord.  On top of that, it is very easy to make some "bad choices" by mistake in the beginning due to the nature of the choice not being particularly clear.

Be warned: you may want to play through this game multiple times to get both endings -- don't.  The difference in how things play out is one line of text and the end credits music.  It's fine to just watch the ending you don't get on YouTube if you're curious.  I can see myself playing through the game again just to see how the different choices impact the world overall, but I would not expect any difference if you were unsatisfied with the conclusion.

Overall, I really enjoyed the game.  The style and story were outstanding overall, and the gameplay was engaging enough to be entertaining throughout.  If you're a fan of point-and-click adventures and some existential horror, check it out!

Tormentum - Dark Sorrow is a descent into beautiful, gory, agony. Prepare your gaming soul for the short but powerful ride wherein an unnamed and conveniently amnesiac protagonist finds the brakes on his dead-man's ride cut.

We have such sights to show you, oh yes.
It has to be said that there is a thin line between a homage and plagiarism, and Tormentum is skillfully dancing on that fine edge. Still, if you want to know what HR Giger's artwork would look like in Hell, look no further. Tormentum is a visual tour de force, a hauntingly beautiful marriage of monstrosities, mythological beasts, archetypes, and desolate wastelands. The soundtrack is subtle, never overly present, but packs quite a punch nonetheless. The slow, melancholic tunes, combined with the phantasmagoria played out before you might just affect you harder than you were prepared for.

As for the puzzles, they are rather typical of the genre, but fun nonetheless. However, a major flaw that most of them have in common is that you'll probably be able to solve them on the first try. Aside from the lack of challenge (and thus satisfaction), this also drastically cuts short the play-time, as you'll find yourself solving puzzles at a pace that is simply unreal for the genre. Most people spend less than six hours on their first play-through.

As for the story, this may not be the game's strong point. Though there is a history behind this dark night of the soul, it's not really worth repeating. Some moral dilemmas present themselves as the story unfolds, but considering how little emotional attachment you’ll have to the cast, none of them feel particularly pressing. It's hard to be upset about the fate of characters who were introduced mere minutes ago, no matter how sorry their plight.

Rather, you should sit back and revel in the flow of gruesome images, the spot-on symbolism, and the melancholic sounds. Familiar as the themes and style may be, Tormentum is something you probably haven't seen before.

[u]Final judgement:[/u] the aesthetics save this game from eternal damnation. [b]7/10[/b]

PROS/CONS:
+ Amazing visuals
+ Good soundtrack
+ Fun puzzles
- Too easy
- Too short

In fact, Tormentum might feel more enjoyable if played by someone with little other experience in point-and-clicks or puzzle games, as its biggest sin is having gameplay that is wholly unoriginal. The game begins in an entirely typical escape-the-room scenario and, while the world does open up and get a bit more unique as it goes, the game never really escapes its use of cliche level design or textbook cookie-cutter puzzles. That's right, sliding tile puzzles, pipe minigames, memory card games, they are all on display.
The writing is similarly trite, feeling a bit in the realm of an emo nineteen-year-old trying terribly hard to sound "edgy." This cringe-inducing neutered darkness extends into the game's art, which seems to be the entire point of it's existence. The game is often little more than a series of static, lovingly-painted stills with little-to-no animation and very little thematically connecting them beyond an apparent desire to look "hardcore." Indeed, the game comes out feeling a bit like someone's artistic portfolio.
Also worth mentioning is the game's hackneyed attempt at imposing a moral choice system on the player, which is predictably obvious and binary and yet at times frustrating as early on the game does a poor job of telegraphing when such choices are taking place, and how the game ends up deciding whether the player recieves the "good" or "bad" ending feels curiously arbitrary.
That being said, the game is functional and pretty, and if you're in the mood for some old-school Newgrounds-style escape-the-room tomfoolery, then this game is plenty adequate.

32832290.review:
(Minor ending spoilers)

I really wanted to like this game. It was enjoyable for the most part, but there is one huge black mark against it that keeps me from recommending it. Aesthetically it's great. The art is absolutely gorgeous throughout and the sound design is on point. The puzzles aren't really anything to write home about but they're passable and do a good job of slowing you down enough to take in the artwork and music without keeping you stumped for so long you get frustrated. I have no problem with the gameplay or atmosphere.

The reason I can't recommend the game, though, is the writing. Setting aside the frequent grammatical errors and stilted, unnatural dialogue, the game sets up an interesting mystery in an intriguing world in its opening minutes, and promptly squanders it by ignoring what it started and throwing on more and more plot threads that go nowhere. By the end, the entire plot is completely dropped to make way for the most disappointing ending I've probably ever seen in a game.

Throughout the plot you're given a series of moral choices, usually pretty obvious but sometimes rather ambiguous. Predictably, these decide the ending you get, but at the last second the game turns into a Chick tract, rejecting any moral nuance and judging you as either good or evil based on weirdly Christian standards of right and wrong, right down to an awkward and uncomfortable "suicide is cowardly and dishonorable" moral. The game opens with a quote by Kant which is supposed to prime you to make the right choices, but considering the ending's utter lack of subtlety it might as well have just said "What would Jesus do?"

If you're just in it for the atmosphere and don't have your hopes up for the story, this could still be worth playing, but if you're not in the mood to be preached to, you should probably skip this one.

This game has nice art and music but in terms of what I expect from an adventure game it's sorely lacking. Game is very short and the puzzles provide no real challenge or thought. On one hand this means you probably won't ever get frustrated but it never really gives you any satisfaction. 

The story is as thin as can be and character motivations are extremely lacking. I don't really expect a great story in my adventure games but something that would explain why exploring and puzzling would be appreciated. Escaping the prison because I don't want to die is fine but trying to find a some random statue just because my character saw it in a dream is not so great. This also makes the morality system kind of laughable as your character is never given any motivation to be good or bad until the very end of the game when its too late. At first I thought the system was there to make a statement about how choices can be morally ambiguous until you make them, but no, letting people live is always good and killing people is always bad. This line of thinking also applies even to religious fanatics who run prison castles designed to torture and kill those they view as impure and birds that sell out an entire town of people for some eggs. I have to say though that I did like the design of choices for the painter's quest. If there were more decisions to make that were as interesting as that one this would be a much better game.

If I was to recommend this game based on something it would be the art style and music. However, the gameplay is so shallow that you're probably better off just watching a let's play or walkthrough or perhaps just listening to the OST on youtube. I came into this game knowing nothing about the concept or what to expect from the story. I have to say, this took some time to get into, but it was worth it.

My first impression, after the first couple of puzzles, was that this game is style over substance. In my puzzle games, I expect there to be a logical, contextual reason behind why they appear. The vast majority of Tormentum's puzzles appear to exist for the sake of the puzzle, which initially put me off. It was hard to get a good grip on how the world and characters function. [b]However[/b], the gorgeous art and surreal tone made me continue playing, and I got a hunch about how this could all make sense. I saw it through to the end, and despite my earlier negative thoughts about the story and setup, I ended up really enjoying it and valuing the experience.

It's a neat little story that took me four hours to complete, and I feel my time was well spent. It's nothing exceptionally original when you break it down, but it's presented through unusual setups that match the solid stylistic choices. The writing matches Giger's art style beautifully.

I would say that its price tag is perhaps a little high for what gameplay you get out of it, as I don't think there is a whole lot of replay value. On the other hand, there must have been incredible time and effort put into all the art in this game, and with that in mind the game is cheap.

Tormentum is dark and beautiful without making me feel like it's trying too hard to be edgy or disturbing, and it left me appreciating the experience. In the end I have to recommend it.

30721693.review:
This game is pure art and an experience. I took certain paths in my first playthrough and fully intend to replay enough to make all the other choices. The world the game takes place in, is essentially a living Zdzislaw Beksinski painting with a little Hieronymus Bosch and H.R. Giger thrown in. That in itself was enough of a selling point for me, but I also really enjoyed the narrative and the puzzles. 

Some people who have played this game are upset about the way the morality works, but I think its fine if you remember the lens this world is viewed through. It's more mercy/compassion vs torture/suffering than a good vs evil dichotomy - which works pretty well, especially when you consider works of the artists that inspired this game. Other heavy themes are redemption and not passing harsh judgement on others, even on those who made very bad mistakes. I think that's pretty important considering the main character has obviously done something wrong (even though the exact nature of what, is a mystery until the end). But if you believe no one deserves a second chance, why should one be extended to you?  

I didn't necessarily personally agree with one specific choice, but I also understood why it was that way. Also you have to play more than once to get the endings + achievements and its fairly short, so multiple playthroughs are encouraged anyway.

I really enjoyed this game a whole lot but I also love all the artists that inspired this game and am always interested in any sort of philosophical or psychological story. I recommend it, especially if these things appeal to you as well.

30386160.review:
The game is a little too expensive. It's relatively short, and really easy. I'm really disappointed in it. Okay, I admit, because of an article (and the overwhelmingly positive reviews?) I'd read, I expected it to be REALLY GREAT, but even without that, I still would've been disappointed. So I think it's not an unfair judgement.

I want to at least start with the positive thing - the art. Clearly inspired by the works of H.R. Giger. At one point there are monsters that are pretty much copy+paste Alien. Also, there's a cute kitty that makes a real kitty sound, it's adorable. However, the game only takes up like half of my screen (in "full screen"), so I could hardly see anything well enough to really appreciate it. It makes it more disappointing though that the art had such a potential that completely went to waste.

Pretty much everything else is either bland or just bad.
- The mechanics of the game are kinda annoying. I know, in point&click games, you shouldn't expect too many shortcuts, but really, the screen scrolling with every move of the mouse when my laptop is just a little bit slow doesn't help. Also, having to open the bag each time to take an item out of it (at least the bag is not an extra screen), come on! Maybe there are games where the clumsiness of it is a good thing, but this one doesn't make up for the clumsiness.
- There's a lot lot LOT of mini-puzzles that have nothing to do with the game and are there just to make it last longer and seem more difficult, I guess. Yeah, yeah, I get it, before I open this door, I have to put an item into it, and then solve the puzzle which really doesn't require a lot of thinking, mostly just a lot of clicking. And then do the same thing ten times more.
- It's really easy. There isn't really much thinking about what item to use where, and that's not a bad thing, but my problem is that there aren't really any riddles. Just put this ball into this ball-shaped box and retrieve the item you need for that character who asked for it, so they can give you an item to put in another puzzle. But not before solving two mini-puzzles, of course.
- Also, the game doesn't really let you find stuff out on your own. The moment you enter a room, all the spots that need interaction start glowing. And don't get me wrong, I don't like those games that hide the important item in that one pixel you have to find after walking around for two hours and finally just resolving to scanning the whole screen with the cursor. But what they did here is kind of the exact opposite, and it's going too far. And to be honest, the one time I did really get stuck, it was because I missed an arrow to another room. They didn't make those glow for some reason.
- OH, also, remember clues you didn't realise were clues until you came across the puzzle you needed them for? Remember making notes? That must've been too 90's for the makers of this game. The character writes down everything he deems useful in a notebook he somehow has at all times. Yes, it absolutely is convenient, and it's also absolutely ridiculous.

But what most surprised and disappointed me is the dissonance between the reviews and the actual game, about the atmosphere and plot. Plot, what plot? It hardly has any. The game really tries to be super dark and atmospheric, and that's it. It tries. And fails. Honestly, I was hoping for creepy stuff! The art is helping, but it's not enough on its own, and I could barely see it (also, the screenshots on the store page are way brighter than in my game, but I didn't see any graphics options. I don't know if this is my laptop's fault). All the game does is talk about suffering. Wow, so deep. Very suffering. Much dark. I'm so moved. Also, you get choices that you have to make that are basically "do the good thing or do the bad thing", but nothing is as it seems! And it may turn out that you ended up doing the opposite. So eye-opening! The game doesn't even let you ponder  in peace how boring the plot "twist" was, the character sums it up with a big ol' moral of the story. And dear god, how didactic this whole game is, especially at the end. I got the feeling like it was intended for ten year olds. Also, at least in my (negative) ending, the credits get some pop metal song that really doesn't fit all the other music and overall theme of the game, and it's really pretty cringeworthy. The credits sum up the whole game: it really wants to be DARK, and it really isn't. And that's just sad.

30115433.review:
[h1]Description[/h1]

Tormentum is a dark point-and-click adventure game taking place in a hellish world inspired by the paintings of H.R. Giger and Zdzislaw Beksinski as well as the atmosphere of Dark Souls and Dark Seed franchises. Every level looks like a painting and the game is peppered not only with the usual puzzles but also with moral choices that will slightly influence the world around the protagonist and be reflected in the ending.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*] Nightmares have never looked so good
[*] Interesting moral choices
[*] Logical puzzles requiring little back-and-forth
[*] Impressive and oppressive atmosphere
[*] In-game hints to alleviate some of the puzzles
[*] Pixel hunting alleviated by pickable objects shimmering
[*] Good varitey of puzzles, none of which last long enough to outstay their welcome
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*] Replay value hindered by the inability to load back to a previous state
[*] Very gorey, though gore is artistically rendered
[*] Bleak from start to finish
[/list]

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

Look at the screenshots and if the art style appeals to you in any way, you owe it to yourself to play Tormentum.

If the art style leaves you indifferent, but you really enjoy brain-teasers that are tricky enough to make you feel smart when you solve them, but straightforward enough not to require random tries, try the demo, chances are you will like this game.

You should only stay away from this game if you despise the art style or the bleak atmosphere.

[h1]P&C в мире Dark Souls [/h1]

Я бы назвал эту игру практически идеальной 2D/P&C игрой. С первых скришотов в магазине в игре наблюдается хорошо прорисованный мир, арты из которого можно без обработок ставить на рабочий стол или оформление страницы в стиме. Сложных загадок, считаю, нет (это же не Myst и не Syberia), все активные области находятся в пределах 4-5 экранов, а чаще и на одном. В эту игру отлично играть вечером после трудового дня для поднятия настроения или читая параллельно что-нибудь из темного фентези или того же Лавркафта. 

Прошел игру пока что один раз, на хорошую концовку. Но фактически игру нужно пройти дважды, чтобы разблокировать все ачивки (довольно легкая игра для 100% авчивок). В целом одно прохождение занимает около 1,5-2 часов не особо быстрых кликов по экрану с залипанием на какую-нибудь особенно приглянувшуюся локацию.

Немного о том, что понравилось и нет

[h1] Сюжет / Атмосфера [/h1] 
+ Атмосферы в игре сколько угодно. На каждом экране можно просидеть несколько десятков минут просто разглядывая рисовку и, скажем так, окунаясь в тот мир, что представлен перед тобой. Каждая локация (Замок, Пустошь, Деревня и холм) прорисованы детально. Художники и дизайнеры прораболи каждый элемент фона и игра реально цепляет тем, что вобрала в себя многие элементы, используемые в серии настолок MTG и оформлении фентези книг конца 90х годов и начала 00х. И да, действительно многим напоминает серию Dark и Demon`s Souls.

- На сюжет можно особо внимания не обращать, да и врядли он чем-нибудь удивит, предсказать финал можно с самого начала. 

[h1] Графика / Рисовка [/h1]
+ Главное достоинство игры и одновременно причина покупки. Как уже сказал выше, прорисовано все очень детально. Каждый обьект на экране хочется рассматривать и рассматривать. Можно даже охарактеризовать игру как "арт-наркотик", настолько сильно она воздействуте при попмощи визуальной составляющей. 

- Периодически выдает 18-20 fps... Серьезно.  

[h1] Загадки [/h1]
+ Ничего сложного, проходится просто и быстро. Можно легко поднять ЧСВ чувством "ух-ты какой я умный" =)
- Все же хотелось бы челенжа, хоть какого-нибудь.

[h1] Звук [/h1]
+ Он есть


[h1] И в конце [/h1]

Даже если вы не любитель таких игр, если считаете, что если загадлка решается за 2 минуты, то это не загадка, все равно очень советую ознакомиться с игрой. С ее рисовкой, ее проработкой локаций. Мне кажется игра вполе способна вновь вызвать у вас те же чувства, что вы когда-то испытали, взяв в руки свой первый том фентези с иллюстрациями. Вау-эффект обеспечен. 30039892.review:
[b]  Tormentum -Dark Sorrow	[/b] ist ein Indie-Point´n´Click- Adventure eines kleinen polnischen Entwicklerteams namens "OhNoo Studio"



Der Name ist hier Programm:Tormentum bedeutet auf Latein: Qual ode Strafe. 
Das Thema zieht sich durch das ganze Spiel. Wer bin ich, warum bin ich hier, wofür soll ich bestrafft und gequält werden?

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=866046642

[h1] Die Grafik [/h1]

Hier ist das Spiel einzigartig. Die Figuren und die Umgebung sind allersamt schaurig schön. Der Grafikstil wurde, laut den dem Etwicklerteam, von H.R. Giger und Zdzislaw Beksinski beeinflusst. (Giger ist durch seine Alien-Kunstwerke bekannt, Beksinski musste ich nachgoogeln.Er hat auch sehr interessante Bilder geschaffen.)Was man zu sehen bekommt, hat was vom Stil beider Künstler, erweckt aber nie den Eindruck einer Kopie.Leid und Tod sind hier immer gegenwärtig. 

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=867742665

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Man sucht Gegenstände, sammelt sie auf, benutzt sie an anderen Orten. Das klassische Point´n´click halt. Das Spiel ist nie besonders schwer und Gegenstände im Inventar muss man nicht kombinieren. Es gilt auch einige Anleitungen zu finden, mit denen sich die Rätsel im Spiel lösen lassen. Bereiche, die abgeschlossen sind, kann man nicht nochmal besuchen.Bei vielen Aufgaben hat man die Möglichkeit zwischen der guten und der dunklen Seite zu wählen, was zum Schluss ( wo diese Entscheidungen ausgewertet werden) zu einem guten oder schlechten Ende führt.Interessant ist auch die Entwicklung einiger Nebencharaktere.Nichts ist so wie es scheint.
Die Musikuntermalung ist stimmig ohne aufdringlich zu wirken. Sprachausgabe gibt es keine, hat mich aber nicht gestört.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=867127840

[h1] Errungenschaften [/h1]

Es ist erforderlich das Spiel mindestens zwei mal zu spielen um 100% zu erreichen.
Gründe:
1. Für jede Entscheidung, böse oder gut, gibt es eine Errungenschaft. Da es nur einen Spielstand gibt, ist voriges Speichern nicht möglich.
2. Es ist erforderlich,  das Spiel als gut und als böse abzuschliessen, wobei gut deutlich schwerer sein könnte (Ich habe ausser 2 Entscheidungen alles als gut erledigt und hatte ein böses Ende).
3.Die schwerste Errungenschaft dürfte "Das Absolute Gedächtnis" sein. Hier darf man das ganze Spiel lang den Notizblock nicht benutzen. Dafür empfehle ich beim ersten Durchlauf alle Notizen die man findet, als Screenshot zu speichern.

[h1] Fazit [/h1]

Ich empfehle das Spiel jedem, der eine einzigartige, düstere Geschichte erzählt bekommen möchte und Point´n´click-Adventures mag. Humor sucht man hier vergebens und wer auf schwere Knobelei steht, könnte hier enttäuscht werden.Ebenso Leute, die ein langes Spiel erwarten.

29385006.review:
Tormentum the Dark Sorrow is an adventure game lush with macabre imagery. 

THE LOOK

This stuff would have been extra stylish and cool at the age of 12 or so. If we had done a schooltrip to a museum with these kind of paintings, my regard of the school system would have been much improved. Alas, we never did go to such a museum. 

Now, somewhat later, the visions of Tormentum appear almost cheery in their visceral glossyness, like a gallery of old paintings of hell drawn by the ghost writer for H.R. Giger. With the overflowing amount and the fantastical consistency of the presentation, the emotional effect it all creates quickly trails towards calm acceptance. A world made of grinning, impaled skeletons, buildings and beings twisted, everything torn and burning and contorted and in the process of dying... it becomes the new normal. Its like listening to three Cannibal Corpse records in a row while looking intently at the covers.

THE MOOD

Tormentum is macabre, not scary. Despite all the pain and suffering and cruelty portrayed, the game does not relate these but rather a slight mood of melancholy. The cryptic tangle of the art evokes mild curiosity.

THE CAST

The characters are laconic and somehow matter of fact, giving occasionally a detached feeling. Perhaps the lack of voice acting is part of the reason.

THE CHALLENGE 

You need to avoid a grizzly fate, so off to puzzle solving you go. The puzzles are easy, there's a lot of handholding. Sometimes the solutions are handed right out somewhere, you'll just have to look. Its always obvious which solution solves which puzzle. To gauge the easiness, you'll find much more challenging puzzles in the Wadjet games, and the brain-melters like the Myst series belong to a different galaxy entirely. As an interesting twist however, unlike in many adventure games, Tormentum actually allows you to choose what you do, sometimes. This is nice, although when these choices are moral, it is often easy to figure out after a moment of reflection which direction the choices likely point to. 

THE VERDICT

Unusual, macabre experience and as such worth a look. Not a horror game in the sense of "boo!" or "yikes!" sensations -- unless something like Clark Ashton Smith books or the old testament manages to scare you. Somehow childish narrative. In difficulty, a casual game rather than an adventure game. Can be played through in a few hours without walkthrough.

From an aesthetic standpoint, this game is darkly boroque. Literally grotesque, and suffused with an atmosphere of worrisome doom. Its artwork and score work wonderfully together, blending the alien, the unknowable, and the surreal.

It's morality system sneaks up on you, as it should for the game's ultimate message. I won't say more, the more to preserve the experience of letting it unfold for you.

This is a masterpiece of gamecraft. If you like dark fantasy, point and click puzzle solving, and moral complexity this is a must-have for your library.

[quote=Immanuel Kant] Aja de modo que considere a humanidade tanto na sua pessoa quanto na de qualquer outro, e sempre como objetivo, nunca como simples meio. [/quote]

Tormentum - Dark Sorrow é um jogo Indie de [i] Point-and-click [/i] com temática dark. Seu forte é, sem dúvidas, a inspiração nos mestres Zdzisław Beksiński e H.R. Giger, com uma temática extremamente macabra e melancólica. 

O jogo conta com uma história em ritmo um pouco lento, porém marcante e que faz você muitas vezes se questionar sobre a sua própria humanidade. Ao decorrer você se encontrará em situações de escolhas que poderão, ou não, ser importantes no final do jogo. Os puzzles são relativamente fáceis, mas terão muitas situações em que você vai ficar perdido procurando a saída, e quando achar, vai querer socar o teclado de tão ridículo.

Vale a pena ressaltar a quantidade de personagens diferenciados que podem ser encontrados ao longo do game. Não tem nenhum que chega a ser muito "marcante", mas conforme o jogo passa, é praticamente impossível não se pegar pensando neles.

A trilha sonora é outro fator espetacular. Com músicas que te passam sensação de tristeza, melancolia, claustrofobia, e em algumas situações, esperança.

Considero o preço do jogo mediano, devido ao fato dele ser bem curto (completei em 3 horas), mas ainda assim vale ser adquirido pela experiência. O jogo conta também com uma demo gratuita para os que se sentirem na dúvida.

Tormentum é um jogo que te faz questionar se certas ações são certas ou erradas. Com uma trilha sonora e direção de arte fantásticas, com certeza é um título que vale a pena ser adquirido.

Jednym zdaniem: Tormentum - Dark Sorrow to nie tylko gra, ale wręcz artystyczne arcydzieło, godne umieszczenia w galerii sztuki. To gra mówiąca o ludzkim cierpieniu, ukryta pod płaszczykiem najlepszego klimatu dark fantasy, jaki kiedykolwiek powstał. Iście zachwycająca wizualnie podróż w otchłań, z której nie ma powrotu. Jeżeli mówią Wam coś takie nazwiska jak Giger czy Beksiński, to wiecie czego się spodziewać... Cierpienie - Mroczny Smutek (Żal) - ten tytuł doskonale opisuje zarówno klimat, jak i temat tej znakomitej, w dodatku polskiej gry.

Plusy:

+ sugestywna atmosfera dark fantasy (tak gęsta, że pająk mógłby tkać pajęczynę;))
+ mocna inspiracja dziełami Gigera (twórca xenomorpha i scenografii w filmowym Alienie)
+ fenomenalna, rysowana grafika na poziomie artystycznym
+ nawiązania stylistyczne do malarstwa Beksińskiego oraz Siudmaka 
+ baaardzo klimatyczna muzyka budująca upiorny apokaliptyczny nastrój w grze
+ galeria ciekawie zaprojektowanych postaci
+ enigmatyczna, wciągająca fabuła
+ trudne moralnie wybory 
+ dobrze zbalansowany poziom zagadek (nie są ani za łatwe, ani za trudne)
+ bardzo wygodny, doskonale zaprojektowany interfejs
+ dopracowanie detali do najmniejszego szczegółu
+ dwa różne zakończenia (ciekawie pomyślane)

Minusy:

-  brakuje emocjonalnej więzi z bohaterem
- wątek fabularny jest zbyt mało rozbudowany (fabuła ujawnia się dopiero pod sam koniec)
- wcale niełatwo zdobyć te dobre zakończenie, bo wystarczy jedna zła decyzja w grze i.. mamy złe zakończenie ;)

Podsumowanie:

Tormentum to dzielo wybitne, zdecydowanie wykraczające poza świat rozrywki komputerowej. Tormentum polecam miłośnikom gatunku dark fantasy i mrocznych, niepokojących klimatów. Polecam też adeptom malartwa i tym którzy uwielbiają wizualny artyzm w grach. Polecam graczom lubiącym dobrze zaprojektowane gry point and click z dobrze wyważonymi łamigłówkami. Wreszcie polecam tym graczom, ktorzy lubią podejmować trudne, moralnie dwuznaczne wybory. Odradzam tylko tym graczom, którzy szukają bardzo rozbudowanej flinii fabularnej i emocjonalnej więzi z bohaterem, bo tego tutaj niestety brakuje.

Rada 1: 

Jeżeli zachwycają Cię obrazy Beksińskiego czy Gigera, to koniecznie musisz zasmakować Tormentum!

Rada 2: 

Jeżeli kiedyś czytaliscie książki z serii Mroczna Wieża i jestesćie jej fanami, to koniecznie zagrajcie w Tormentum, bo polscy deweloperzy w dużej mierze inspirowali się klimatem słynnych powieści Stephena Kinga.

Rada 3: 

Jeżeli gracie w Tormentum, to... nie ufajcie nikomu. W tym świecie nic nie jest takie proste, jak się wydaje. ;)

While i really like this games art and the puzzles are good, i cant recommend it.

SPOILERS BEYOND HERE


At the end, you learn this is all basiclaly a test in the afterlife for whether your soul can change. This is kinda crap but i could forgive it if it didnt act like the moral authority on some of its more complex questions. 

An example, should you give a crown rumored to give large ammounts of power to a lizard man who just appears racist to bird people and is kinda a demanding jerk? Or your rat friend you saved from prison (or killed earlier, idk what happens then) so that he can protect his family? The rat also eats people, but the lizard really seems like the kinda guy to abuse that power.

The right decision is to give it to the lizard supposidly, because the rat goes into war and dies if you give it to him. How are you supposed ot know beyond a slip in one of his drawers about an offer for him to join an army? Why is it your fault that you didn't know that the crown only works for those pure of heart?

Another example, at the beggining there is a  jailer who only lives to torture people mercillessly, and was going to kill you. About halfway through the first level your given the option to spare or kill him. The right answer is to spare him because "who are you to decide who lives and dies?"


It has some ok moral quandaries, like whether or not to kill the rat guy early on who has only been nice to you, whether or not to ruin some blind guys paintings just to save time getting a blueprint, whether or not to help someone who is living in constant agony, whether to kill or save the guy the rats were going to eat, etc. This is all Stuff that you can morally go to and say "yes thats good, no thats bad" to most people because its so brain dead stupid what the right choices are.

I don't directly blame the devs for this issue mind, having any complex answers with a black and white morality system is incredibly hard to do right. No, I blame it for using these complex situations at the end for measuring the ending you get. It should have been left to the player to decide whether they were right or wrong, else it just comes off as condescending, biased, or based in religious beliefs.

I won't say that you cant have a game with these kinds of opinions, where the idea of what is "right" is one of the three i said earlier. It just needs to be handled better, a good example being the beginners guide. While the beginners guide asks some far different questions, they are just as complex as the ones in this game. It never answers them, or uses your choices to determine an ending. No, instead the beginners guide ends with hinting at the writers idea of what is "morally right," without ever outright saying that he IS right.

Either way, in the case of this game, the ending prolly shouldnt have relied on these morality questions. Instead, it should have just had a singular ending that leaves everything grey. You dont need to write every interesting part about a characters story, just to where it needs to end.

In my opinion if the game ended 5 minutes earlier i woulda said its amazing, even if the game never explained itself itd fit the artistic style and world so much better. If it ended at that point, it would just be you riding an elevator down for what seems like eternity, remembering a phylisophical idea about what youve experienced and require the player to answer the questions on their own. They could expand that and hint at their ideas of what was right and wrong, maybe having the character just remembering his life and why he was there, and what the stakes were. If they did that, it would have had just enough hinting at the bias the writers had without slapping it in my face.


Overall, amazing art, good puzzles (few head scratchers but no bullshit,) and overall a nice well optimized game with decent story. The ending just felt condescending and religiously focused, and i cant overlook that.

Everything was very straight forward and there wasn't really anything that you needed to figure out or explore. The puzzles might as well not have been in the game because they were ridiculously fast and easy. I felt like that they weren't suitable for the age group that this game is trying to target.

The story is very linear and your choices have very little impact on the story (with the exception of the ending, which was boring and cliche). Overall the story was very weak and I wish that it had expanded more on world and characters. The morals that the story pushes onto the player were also frustrating because it forces the player to see plot decisions as black and white with no in between. 

The only positive that I found with this game are the visuals which were amazing and the soundtrack. Visually, this is a great game but it's short, underdeveloped, and has little replay value besides achievements.

29010675.review:
Tormentum - Dark Sorrow - это оживший коллективный разум разработчиков из OhNoo Studio (Польша) Главный герой появляется в неком неизвестном для него месте (позже узнаем где) Он абсолютно не помнит своего прошлого. Во время игры всё больше падаешь в эту безумную пропасть мрака, страха и бессилее персонажей этого мира. Один из первых встречающих персонажей это крыса. Просящий найти ключ и освободить его из заточения, в обмен на благодарность. Сложно объяснить, что происходит и почему - нужно просто попробовать и постараться переварить.

На протяжении всего пути нам предстоит исследовать пугающие локации, решать разнообразные загадки и общаться с местными жителями.  Стоит встретить кого-нибудь с хорошо подвешенным языком и на вас мигом бросят свои проблемы, попросят или вынудят посодействовать. И тут в дело вступает обещанная вариативность: например, можно помиловать или казнить палача, а у крысы например более скрытый подтекст действий, о которых мы узнаем к финалу. (Её гнилой образ за личиной положительного) Последствия некоторых поступков очевидны, другие лишь косвенно влияют на финал. И до самого конца остаётся гадать, правильный ли сделан выбор и к чему это в итоге приведёт. Да и сами ситуации весьма неоднозначные.

Главный козырь Tormentum: Dark Sorrow – охренительная рисовка. Художники вдохновлялись Гигером, но, конечно, без Дали и Босха тут тоже не обошлось. [u]Впрочем, у пшеков свои давние художественные традиции сюрреализма, так что, возможно, создатели «Торментума» частично черпали идеи из работ мэтра Здислава Бексинского и Гжегоша Кмина.[/u]

Чтобы получить «хорошую» развязку, нужно принимать исключительно правильные (с точки зрения игры) решения, некоторые из которых, между тем, кажутся сомнительными с точки зрения здравого смысла и даже морали, а также ввиду недостатка информации. Например, понять кто такие на самом деле шут и королева можно лишь после прохождения.

[i]Спустя 5 часов стоя перед статуей отпущения грехов приходишь к выводу: под маской игры скрывается притча о значении выбора и последствиях поступков. Всё приключение игрок находился в чистилище, где нас испытывали, взвешивали наши поступки для перехода в другой мир. Вам решать насколько положительным он будет[/i]. 7.5\10.

But beyond this wonderful eye candy, the gameplay is fairly simple. Simple to the point where it could be considered a negative as the puzzles in this game are easy. Ingame you even have a notebook to which you can remember certain drawn clues you may find in throughout the levels. There was even one puzzle which I ended up solving by accident by clicking around with little thought. So don't come into this game expecting a challenge, it's not about that. Tormentum is a game of experience! It immersives you into this world through its imagery and as well as the moral choices you'll make in this game. A few of these choices may seem black and white and some will be controversial as some people in the steam forums can attest. But regardless of your choice, the beauty of this all is how Tormentum gets you to stop and think about what you're going to do.

A point-and-clilck with WTFs in all the right places.
The visuals so gigery it's outstanding, the music is atmospheric, and the surroundings are weird and disturbing enough. The puzzles, on the other hand, are logical and simple, with some nicely balanced mini-games in between. No pixelhunting. No hardcore music puzzles. No brainfucking “originality” — you would use a lamp for lighting a room and a skinning knife for skinning a creature, not vice versa. At 3 hours of casual gameplay, maybe that's even a bit too easy.

The only downside is the forced black-and-white morality.
Still, as indie games go, I'd call Tormentum a piece of art.

Tormentum smoothly combines point-and-click adventure with classic puzzle gameplay, a horrific artistic theme, and silent protagonist storytelling. 

The game took me <4 hour to beat, and has limited replayability given that you will already know how to solve all the puzzles. That said, I thoroughly enjoyed every minute of gameplay, and never found myself skimming and skipping any element. The world is so thoughtfully put together that within each and every background there is beauty to be found. From the smallest details to the grander scope of world view, the one continuous sense of a living, breathing world will spark your curiosity to dive yet deeper into the miasma.

A common gripe I have with puzzle games is when my post-disbelief-suspended limitations misalign with the programmed gameplay elements (e.g. Why can't I just walk between these gate bars that are clearly wide enough to pass thorugh?) Tormentum weaves its horror so immersively that I found myself intuitively understanding the world around me and how to navigate it. 

I overwhelmingly recommend Tormentum - Dark Sorrow.

Edit:

I have two criticisms of this game. I wanted MOAR, and;

There is a "choices matter" gameplay element that I was a huge fan of all the way up to the very end of the game at which point it lazily falls back on a patronizing deontological ethics lens.

There's no real challenge, puzzles are braindead easy. You'll finish the game in one sitting, in about 2-3h. I felt a bit tricked, because Tormentum is basically a visual novel - point&click elements like puzzles are here only to prolong the expierence.  And it's all eye-candy, sure.... but it terms of content, it's lacking. It's funny how you are encouraged to play it again, to see different ending... Yeah, because it is short and you will want to squeeze more value from your purchase.  

Well, most achievements are about binary choices, so you'll need to finish the game at least twice to get them all. Well, I'm not looking forward to it. I'm not even starting on moral issues that this game evokes... and you'll be conflicted about few things that Tormentum says about life and death. 

Personally, i got the "bad" ending and plenty of You will get it too. I got like 80% "good" decisions, but overall  - i was judged as a bad person, even when i chose to repent and acknowledge that i wasnt perfect. That was... a bit off. 
Well, i still recommend it - in terms of visuals and sound, it's astonishing, but don't except to be blow away by the story...

I received this game as a christmas present, but not for a review of any kind. The game completely inspired me to rave about it.

Much like games like Journey, or Flower, this is much more of a provacative art piece. You play as a lost soul, imprisoned in a castle with no memory of who you are or how you got there. All you have to go on is a dream you've been having repeatedly.

This game forces moral decisions on you in a style reminscent of Mass Effect. Unlike the ME series, I found myself wanting to go back and replay to see what would have happened had I chosen the other path.

The music and art are, in a word, exquisite. Immediately recognizable as a love letter to H.R. Giger (even saying as much on the game's main site) as well as a definite Lovecraftian horror in the atmosphere and creature design. 

I really can't rave enough about this game. It's a two hour journey through a gorgeous, haunting visual ride, complete with puzzles, a thought provoking story and a sense of emotion that stays with you after the credits. It's low cost, for a high return. Pick it up.

【游戏都没通的还是别在我的评测下面留言了】
冲着那冲击力极强的画风入的，没失望。通关之后字幕里穿插的插画和教堂关卡里那三十多张油画也都证明了这个制作组的艺术水准可能性（让你去期待续作）。
但是这游戏有我不能忍受的一个缺点。“做出选择影响结局好坏”这种本来应该值得称道的设计，实际玩起来却让我反感，其原因就是制作组用这个设计试图向我输出他们的价值观：宽恕、忍让、博爱。
我是来玩游戏的，不是来听你说教的。为什么我因为快意恩仇杀掉仇人你就要判定这是恶行？而我假惺惺地原谅一个恶徒就会被你说是高尚的善行？结局部分用一个“判官”来对玩家之前的选择一个个点评，更是暴露出制作组那种高高在上的姿态。
更可笑的是，这些选择都是“too young，too simple”，“善选择”和“恶选择”都太过明显，你一眼就能看出制作组葫芦里卖的是什么药，最后结果是玩家只会为了追求好结局去做选择，而不是听从自己内心，导致代入感全无。
游戏真正的好善恶选择设计，不是通过选择影响结果好坏让你“顿悟”那些都被说烂了的普世价值（就像谁需要一样），而是选哪一个都差不多，最后却能让你产生思考。恭喜这个游戏在这一点上贡献了一个完美的反面教材。

I Bought this game based on the description "Point & Click adventure". Being a fan of games like Discworld & secret of monkey island I was hoping for a bit of nostalgia and some casual puzzle solving.

Here's a breakdown of Tormentum.

[b]Pros:[/b]
Game play is straightforward
Items and puzzles are easily identifiable and often have audio cues to help
Good puzzle variety
Good range of puzzle difficulty (Depending on your experience with puzzles)
Great soundtrack
Amazing artwork (Very dark and unnerving)
Interesting characters
Very little back-tracking
Choices to make / Alternate endings
Translated for multiple languages

[b]Subjective:[/b]
Didn't find the "story" very enthralling
Final sentiment conflicted with personal morality
Good length of game for my taste, not too long and not too short

[b]Cons:[/b]
A single puzzle near the end can cause a lot of confusion due to a lack of explanation
Despite meeting many interesting characters, encounters were often brief with little more than a fetch quest
Depending how fast you are, the game could only take you a few hours to complete and even less the second time

[b]Overall:[/b]
Tormentum is a great point and click game, especially for anyone who enjoys a dark and eerie art style reminiscent of Zdzisław Beksiński's work.

28640228.review:
Tormentum - Dark Sorrow ist ein sehr interessantes Spiel.

Hauptaugenmerk liegt auf dem wirklichen beeindurckenden Artstyle, was auch der größte Pluspunkt des Spiels ist. Vor allem wenn man abstrakte und düstere Darstellungen mag. Die abwechslungsreichen Charaktere und Umgebungen erzeugen eine sehr düstere, spannende Atmospähre. Man ist trotzdem jedes mal neugierig, was einem im nächsten Bildschirm erwartet.
Was außerdem hervorzuheben ist, sind die Entscheidungen, die man im Spielverlauf treffen muss.
Ich kann nicht beurteilen, ob die Entscheidungen die Story wirklich beeinflussen, das werde ich aber in einem zweiten Durchlauf testen.
Das Spiel selbst ist ziemlich kurz (ich habe ca. 4 Stunden benötigt) und auch sehr einfach. Es gibt kaum eine Stelle an der man viel überlegen muss. Es gibt einige Rätsel, jedoch folgt deren Lösung fast immer direkt nachdem man sie entdeckt hat. 
Das widerum hat mir die Atmospähre des Spiels ein wenig getrübt, da es gerade in solch einer komplex wirkenden Welt einfach gewesen wäre, ein paar komplexere Rätsel einzubauen. 
Des Weiteren hätte ich mir gewünscht, dass man in diesem Spiel sterben kann. In gefährlichen Situationen kommt lediglich eine Warnung und der Held verweigert die Aktion. Das ist Schade, denn da alles in dieser Welt bedrohlich wirkt wäre das eine authentische Funktion gewesen, die die Atmoshäre sehr verstärkt hätte (trotz des Speichern/Laden Aufwands).

Also noch einmal zusammengefasst:
Pros:
+ Wunderschöner Artstyle
+ moralische Entscheidungen

Cons:
- (zu) einfacher Schwierigkeitsgrad
- kurze Spieldauer

Fazit:
Tormentum - Dark Sorrow ist auf jeden Fall einen Blick Wert, jedoch nur wenn es im Sale ist. 
Jeder, der diesen Zeichenstil mag, darf beruhigt zugreifen. Ebenfalls alle, die gemütlich in einem etwas düsteren Setting rätseln wollen.
Wer jedoch anspruchsvolles Knobeln und stundenlange Beschäftigung sucht ist hier eher falsch. 

Ich für meinen Teil werde mir die alternativen Entscheidungen auf jeden Fall noch einmal ansehen und in dieser schönen, eigenartigen und beunruhigenden Welt abtauchen.

Excellent jeu d’énigme, narration efficace, visuellement richissime et bluffant, scenario énigmatique mais clair à la fin du titre, Tormentum Dark Sorrow est indéniablement un des meilleurs point n' click disponible sur le catalogue Steam. Il n'est pas un jeu culte, il est juste un hommage sincère fait à un artiste peu connu du grand public, et un jeu qui, dans sa catégorie, est proche du sans faute.

Je vais m'efforcer d’être le plus objectif possible sur la critique de Tormentum Dark Sorrow étant donné que Zdzislaw Beksinski est mon peintre préféré. Sincèrement, même sans ça cela n'aurait absolument rien changé a mon sens car le jeu est excellent en soi.

Ce titre s'inspire de l'univers graphique de Beksinski sans reprendre exactement ses tableaux. Certaines notions qu'on retrouve dans ses œuvres sont pourtant bien présente (les portes monumentales, les constructions metalico-chitineuses, les corps émaciés, les visages dissimulés, les géants inanimés, les lueurs bleues dans un monde rouillé, etc), tout comme certaines situations. La première qui me vient à l'esprit c'est cette personne tenant dans ses bras son enfant mort, penchée au dessus de lui devant le portail du château, qui rappelle le célèbre tableau du peintre ou on y voit un être vêtu de bleu au dessus d'un landau, adossé contre une muraille.

Quand on joue a Tormentum, on sent les fans du surréalisme et du fantastique de Beksinski derrière le développement de ce jeu. On voit qu'il ne se sont pas dit « ouais Beksinski c'est cool on va faire un point n' click avec ses tableau ça va cartonner ». Non. On voit qu'ils ont représenté leur propre interprétation de l'univers du peintre, qu'il ont voulu retranscrire dans leur jeu tout ce que leur inspire son œuvre. Quand vous êtes face à une œuvre de Beksinki, vous êtes transporté sur une autre planète dans une dimension perdue, vous voyez une fenêtre qui donne sur des vestiges oubliés et vous interprétez ce que vous voyez, vous vous figurez ce qui a pu se passer sur ce monde et qui sont les personnages sur le tableau. Les développeurs de Tormentum Dark Sorrow on exactement eu cette démarche, ils se sont imprégnés non pas des tableaux originaux, mais des émotions que ces derniers provoque chez eux et on retranscrit cela dans leurs artworks.

L'histoire du jeu est accès sur la notion d'absolution et de damnation, vous aurez tout au long du jeu des choix à faire qui vous définiront, alors que votre personnage n'est personne, puisqu'il ne sait même pas qui il est ni ou il est. Vous sentez tout au long du jeu que vous traversez une épreuve, à la fois par les énigmes que vous devez résoudre (intéressantes sans être un véritable casse-tête), mais aussi par toutes les rencontres fortes que vous ferez, qui sonnent comme des chapitres de votre voyage.

Je conseille vivement de finir le jeu deux fois, en opérant à chaque fois des choix opposés, afin de connaître les deux fins principales du jeu, qui sont vraiment bien amenées. Mention spéciale aux génériques de fins qui ont tout deux des musiques sublimes et aux artworks post-générique magnifiques. Ont voit vraiment que les développeurs ont aimé chacun de leurs travaux préparatoires, au point de vouloir nous les partager en fin de jeu, merci à eux!

Плюсов в игре больше, так что начать можно с них. Визуально игра выполнена на высшем уровне. Если честно, её можно купить уже только ради рисовки. Каждая локация обладает своим собственным стилем, каждый экран проработан до мелочей. Всё стильно и атмосферно.[spoiler] (Разработчик так любит свои работы, что даже поместил в игру маленький музей.)	[/spoiler] Музыка радует, особенно та, что играет в титрах. Квестовая часть не вызывает ровно никаких проблем. Все действия, которые от вас требуются, сразу понятны. Два часа бегать по экранам и пробовать комбинации типа «вилка+унитаз» не придется- визуал и сюжет здесь в приоритете. Довольно милая идея с системой морали. Все ваши поступки, хорошие и плохие, вам в конце припомнят- в игре две концовки.

Эта игра не вокал Джека Блэка, а, следовательно, в ней есть и недостатки. Первый- пазлы. Я всё понимаю, хочется разнообразить геймплей и сделать игру чуть длинней, но черт возьми, пятнашки?! Серьезно? Можно оставить их, а также составление дисков с рисуночками, цепочки из шестеренок и прочий хлам, в 2005-ом году? Пожалуйста! Второе- система кармы хоть и интересная, но работает немного криво.

Покупайте. Со скидкой, без- неважно. Хороших и оригинальных игр сейчас мало.

Очень интересная и загадочная игра.
Давно прошел эту замечательную игру и только сейчас решил высказать свое мнение по поводу нее. 
Что касается положительных аспектов:

+ Локации:
   Каждый уровень по своему уникален. Прохождение данной игры можно сравнить с походом в картинную галерею.    Ценители искусства и просто эстеты будут полностью удовлетворены визуальной составляющей данной игры. 
Тут прорисовано абсолютно все начиная с фонов локаций и заканчивая квестовыми вещами 
+ Музыка:
   Словами не описать какое в игре музыкальное сопровождение. Для каждой локации здесь предполагается своя музыка, которая невероятно четко передает атмосферу происходящего. Отдельное спасибо разработчикам за шикарное музыкальное оформление финала на 10 баллов из 10.
+ Сюжет: Достаточно мало игр несущих в себе философскую составляющую. Игра заставляет нас задумать над многими важными вопросами. И одним из них является: "А что же меня ждет после того, как я проживу отведенное мне время?". Авторы игры попытались донести до нас свою точку зрения и представления о "том" мире. 
+ Игровая механика: 
   Все задачки доольно простые и решаются достаточно быстро.  Если Вы предпочитаете сложные головоломки, то этот пункт для Вас автоматически становится главным минусом игры.
    
    Игра не дает Вам шанса быть нейтральным. В итоге каждый ваш поступок и каждое ваше действие будет оценено в конце. Вы можете пройти ее только как положительный или как отрицательный персонаж.  А критериев оценки всего 2: "добро" и "зло". Третьего не дано...
    Также в игре есть 34 легко получаемых достижений. Я прошел игру 3 раза, ушло на это 6 часов.

Что касается минусов:

Я не любитель игр такого жанра, но и это не мешает мне сказать, что эта игра великолепна. Сложно выделить в этой игре какие-либо минусы.
Что же в итоге мы получаем заплатив всего 279 рублей:
1) Великолепную атмосферу
2) Шикарное музыкальное сопровождение
3) Захватывающий сюжет
4) 34 легких достижения

Для меня игра стала самым настоящим открытием. Я остался доволен покупкой и не жалею этих денег. Игра заставила задумать над смыслом жизни, выставлением каких-то приоритетов в жизни и над многими другими вопросами нашей с вами жизни. 
Советую эту иигру всем. Она каждого застватит над чем-то задуматься.
Спасибо всемза просмотр данного обзора.

CONS:

-Constantly helped and told what to do, leaving no solving initiative to the player

-Easy and unoriginal puzzles

In my opinion, most games in this genre have a horrible problem of including puzzles that are either too vague to figure out or having solutions that make no sense to anyone except the developers of the game. I've seen some people complaining that the game's puzzles are too easy, but to me, that just means the mechanics were clearly telegraphed, which is the sign of a good game. In my opinion, I shouldn't have to be running around, trying hundreds of different combinations in a desperate attempt to make progress in the game.

The story is pretty basic, but the world they created to host it is not. I almost wish they'd done more with some of these characters in regards to how they interact and where they end up after you're done with them.

The artwork is obviously gorgeous and lends to the experience a lot. 

Sound is pretty good too. I can maybe see why they chose not to, but I think including voice acting for the dialogue would have gone a long way for this game. In general, I think they could have done a little more with the audio to really bring the world to life, but that's just my opinion.

The game is short, but it does encourage at least one replay, so there's that, and it may also seem shorter than other games in the genre just because it's so incredibly well streamlined and clear. If you encounter it on sale and are at all interested, you probably won't be disappointed.

26153569.review:
Writing this as an adventure game veteran there is literally only one reason to play Tormentum: You like spooky art drawn in a Geigeresque fashion. 

Everything else that makes an adventure game good - well thought out puzzles, a good story, and an interesting protagonist - are missing here. The puzzles are very straight forward. You will only get stymied on the non-contextual puzzles - stuff like solving a rubik's puzzle or a literal jigsaw puzzle. Or on areas that require a keycode and you need to find where that password is randomly scrawled in the background. The story is a journey through the artist's conception of purgatory. There is a moral choice system, but you will frequently accidently pick the wrong option not realizing that this WAS a choice that affects the game's ending. Not that it really matters as you can probably finish the whole thing in 6 hours on your first play through. There's not really anything in the way of character development. The complete lack of voice acting is an extreme detractor for a 2016 adventure game.

But if you like lots of pictures of skeletons, sinew, and tendons then this is the game for you. I'd rather play Deponia, Monkey Island, or any of the classic LucasArts games.

Tragically and hauntingly beautiful. Tormentum presents the player with a question of morals, determining a "good" or "evil" choice at various crossroads. Part of the effectiveness in this game's presentation comes from the difficulty in differentiating between which choice is correct. 

Do I save the man being tortured? How do I know he doesn't "deserve" his punishment?
If I murder this guard, what treasures will be mine? He is evil, I am not; therefore his gold should be mine.
She must be innocent.
He is my friend; he helped me escape. Surely there is an explanation for his actions.

Who am I to decide the fate of another?

This is the question posed to the player. Who am I, and what justifies my actions?

Do yourself a favor and set aside 2-3 hours to play through Tormentum in one sitting. The minimalist gameplay combined with vividly drawn settings create a dark atmosphere, immersing the player deep within the world of Tormentum.

Шикарный квест, авторы которого вдохновлялись работами Гигера. Визуальная составляющая здесь по сути выступает краеугольным камнем, с лихвой перекрывая собой некоторые недостатки игры — каждую локацию хочется подолгу рассматривать, словно находишься в арт-галерее.

Главным героем истории выступает персонаж, которого мы не знаем, как зовут, не видим его лица и не знаем его прошлого, поскольку сам герой не помнит своё прошлое да и вообще особо не осознаёт, кто он такой, что уже с самого начала в сюжет добавляет изрядную долю интриги. Доставив в клетке на дирижабле в Замок, героя запирают в камере и сообщают, что его ожидают пытки, дабы изменить его испорченную сущность, которую он сформировал своими поступками в прошлом. Пробираясь через мрачные фантасмагоричные локации, встречая на своём пути не менее причудливых существ и постоянно оказываясь на распутье моральных выборов, в которых зачастую сложно однозначно принять правильное решение, нам предстоит выбраться из Замка и добраться до места, где герой намеревается узнать истину.

+ Дизайн локаций и существ выше всяких похвал.
+ Хорошее музыкальное сопровождение. Хотя местами эмбиент можно было сделать более депрессивным.
+ Общая мрачная и загадочная атмосфера.
+ Сюжет, наличие моральных выборов.

+/- Геймплей в целом стандартен. С одной стороны все совершаемые действия логичны и не вызывают затруднений, что плюс, но с другой стороны — наличие небольшого кол-ва активных предметов и доступных локаций в данный момент вызывают излишнюю простоту, что минус. То же самое касается и загадок / мини-игр — часть из них интересны в решении и на них приходится потратить некоторое время, а некоторые крайне просты и словно перекочевали из какой-нибудь HoG.

- Игра на флеше, игровая область в виде небольшого прямоугольника по центру (настройки по умолчанию). Включение фуллскрина само-собой слегка замылит картинку.
- К минусам также можно отнести отсутствие анимации при выполнении различных действий (происходят при затемнённом экране), а также то, что герой не ходит, а стоит на одном месте — перемещение между локациями происходит нажатием стрелок у краёв экрана (и снова привет HoG).

В целом минусы технического плана незначительные и никак не портят общее впечатление от игры. Настоятельно рекомендую к прохождению.

Оценка: 9 из 10

-The mini-game based puzzles (ie: slide puzzle) are all reasonable and can be solved with just enough effort that you aren't screaming in agony but not so simple that they might as well not be in there. Some were more on the easy side, but none were too simple.
-The writing is wonderfly grim and dark which fits the atmosphere perfectly. There are very few moments you feel as if there's a ray of hope in the grim landscape only for it to be plucked away or for the moment to be ruined by some cruel act. There's a few twists that caught me by surprise and, while very simple, the plot does its job wonderfully.
-The addition of choice was a lovely addition to the game which really gave the feeling that you truely were trying to escape a hellish trial.
-The music is down right amazing and makes me wish I had the sound track.

Cons
-The game is fairly short. I completed it after playing non-stop for about 3-4 hours.
-One of the difficulties with having morality choices in a game is that, sometimes, it's not as black and white as it appears. There's two choices in particular where either you lack enough information to make a good judgement call and/or it could be argued that the "bad" choice isn't a bad choice at all.

Overall, I have VERY few complaints. If you're a fan of point and click adventure games with a love for this kind of artwork and style, it's definitely worth picking up.
