[h1]Visually pleasing, but lacking in gameplay[/h1]

If you're a diehard fan of old school death metal (like I am), you probably know who is Dan Seagrave and what kind of bizarre, surreal and dark worlds he portrays in much of his work. Add a healthy spoonful of Zdzisław Beksiński and a dash of H.R. Giger to go with it, and you pretty much have Tormentum - Dark Sorrow.

The game has superb art direction and everything feels and looks very polished. Music and sound fit the style and the mood of the game perfectly and I just generally tend to enjoy this kind of dark fantasy.

However, the game lacks in length, difficulty and gameplay. The puzzles are very easy and I completed the game twice in just under 4 hours, without ever needing to consult a walkthrough.

The main character just stands still in the scenes, limiting the feel of interactivity in the world. Moving between scenes happens instantaneously, without any walking animations. There is very little text or dialogue in the game. Also the morality of the game is very black-and-white, although the moral choices do have interesting twists.

The price of the game is a bit steep for such a short game with very little gameplay, but if you find it on a sale, I heartily recommend it for an evening of dark fantasy adventure.

This game has some of the best, if not THE best, artwork of certainly any point-and-click I have ever played, and possibly any GAME I have ever played. The music is also fantastic and compliments the sorrowful atmosphere (hey, it ain’t subtitled Dark Sorrow for nothing).

The only fault I can find are some occasional and unfortunate English-as-a-second-language errors and verb-tense switching issues that marred an otherwise decent and philosophical story.
 
None of the puzzles are difficult – some might find them TOO easy; none are obtuse and the game is generous with its hints.   I had to look up a solution only once, and this was simply due to an object I had missed. This made for an enjoyable ride that wasn’t too taxing and removed the frustration that most point-and-click adventures suffer from.

I own too many point-and-click games, but I never actually play any of them. This one I bought, loaded it up, and was compelled to play it from start to finish, putting aside everything else I’m playing at the moment. I think it’s actually the first point-and-click I’ve ever completed. I played through once and received perhaps the neutral ending. I don’t usually play games twice, but I’m considering revisiting this one just to check out the other endings.

I waited for a sale before I bought, but after playing it, I wouldn’t have minded if I hadn’t. 
If you enjoy point-and-click games, are a fan of H.R. Giger, and dig on cruel and oppressive dark fantasy, this game is an absolute must buy and well worth the full asking price.

Habe Tormentum in einem Rutsch nun durchgespielt und hatte sehr viel Spaß dabei.

Über Artstyle müssen wir nicht viele Worte verlieren. Jeder, der Interesse an diesem Spiel hat, der hat es es zu 99,5% genau deswegen. Genau dieser Artstyle lässt einen auch immer weiterspielen, weil man immer wissen will, was einen als nächstes erwartet (ähnlich wie bei Fran Bow).

Spielkonzept geht in die Ecke Point and Click/Hidden Object-Gameecke, aber ohne den Charakter selbst ständig noch bewegen zu müssen. Ist vor allem angenehm für Leute, die aus Erfahrung wissen wie es ist, wenn man ständig hin und her laufen muss und man trotzdem nicht weiterkommt, aber sehr viel Zeit mit herumlaufen vertrödelt.
Das sollte hier eigentlich nicht passieren, da eigentlich alles ziemlich logisch und auch nicht überaus kompliziert ist. Die Objekte sind gut sichtbar. Der Schwerpunkt liegt hier mehr auf der Geschichte und ist somit auch gut geeignet für Leute, die sonst eher Angst vor Point and Click-Frustration haben und sich schon vor Augen halten wie sie bei Google nach nem Guide in Video- oder Textform suchen.

Besonders positiv überrascht hatte mich, dass man immer wieder Entscheidungen fällen darf. Die Auswirkungen sollte jeder für sich selbst herausfinden. Ein zweites Mal durchspielen um alle Achievements zu kriegen ist auf jeden Fall Pflicht. Nach circa 4 Stunden dürftet ihr mit dem ersten Mal durch sein. 

Zum Abschluss sei gesagt, dass hier ein kleines Team ein echt tolles Spiel auf die Beine gestellt hat und ich für 4 Stunden perfekt unterhalten wurde. Nicht zu lang, nicht zu kurz, unterschiedliche Rätsel und keine Frustpausen. Das einzig fehlende war ne Sprachausgabe. Mit ein paar düsteren Sprechern wäre es sicher noch besser geworden die düstere Atmosphäre zu transportieren.
Würde das Spiel jedem Empfehlen, der den Artstyle gut findet. 

PS.: Für alle Untentschlossenen gibts außerdem eh noch die Demo auf Steam.

25292650.review:
" Чтобы оказаться на верху блаженства, иногда приходится скатиться в бездну греха." 
Эдуард Севрус

Мрак, пустота, боль и страдания – такими покажутся грядущие перспективы этой игры. Полное тьмы и забвения путешествие в явно неприятном мире. Мы попадаем в него уже словно с обречением, в качестве героя, который не знает ничего ни о себе, ни о своём прошлом. Ни имён, ни историй, ровным счётом ничего. 

Короткое пребывание в игре запомнится контрастным миром визуального кошмара. Буквально всё напитано ужасом и всевозможными мелкими деталями насыщенной этим атмосферой. В тот же самый момент это усугубляется тяжестью музыкального сопровождения, на нас давят «тяжёлой нотой». В мире этого приключенческого квеста можно найти погружение в бездну самого себя. Нам предстоит бродить по здешним локациям в поисках того, чем бы «поживиться», что взять и куда-нибудь пристроить. Однако всевозможные подсказки, порой до банального документа с полным решением, не вызовут ни малейшего затруднения. Назвать её особо сложной, непонятной или долгой просто невозможно. Каждый «ключ», найденный в игре, в прямом смысле имеет форму, которая пойдёт только к одной «замочной скважине». Игра запомнится именно миром очаровательного мрака. Помимо основного занятия - «тыканья» предметами инвентаря, можно насладиться краткими историями местных обитателей. По сути всё завязано на осмыслении простого решения – убить или спасти. Однако не все «добрые» дела будут такими уж и добрыми. Этот факт порождает большой плюс игры – возможность выбора и, как следствие, факт получения от этого различных концовок.

За основу нашего нахождения в игре взяты постулаты – вопросы, которые персонаж задаёт в начале путешествия. Обидно только за то, что хоть одна ошибка стоит изменения ответов, которые, и так понятно, будут в завершении игры. Порой не всегда легко различить «добро» и «зло», один неверный выбор портит вашу «статистику» перед высшим судом. Забавным фактом остаётся до конца то, что мы, по сути, играем до заключения за непонятное существо. Мир персонажей здесь довольно разнообразный: первым встретившимся будет крыса, в дальнейшем это будут изуродованные в тяжёлой мере люди, а так же различные монстры, охраняющие локации от нашего вторжения до поры до времени. Повстречаются враждующие взгляды на предметы, которые можно отдать только одному. Порой именно моральная сторона сыграет свою роль.

Ни для кого ни секрет, что за основу локаций взяты работы самого Ганса Рудольфа Гигера. Многим он запомнился работой над образом «Чужого», однако работы, которые предстают взору в игре, явно заслуживают не меньшего внимания. Все места, в которых нам предстоит побывать, заполнены мельчайшими деталями, которым явно стоит уделить время для большего наполнения и погружения в мир. Взяв всю прелесть мрачной картины игры и добавив, усиливающих атмосферу кошмарного места, композиций, мы получим приятное путешествие на небольшое количество времени.

The gameplay is simple, the game is short, and it's pretty clear some heavy translation was going on, but my God is this game beautiful. 

The first thing you're probably thinking is that the art forr this game looks like the cover of a heavy metal album. And you would be absolutely correct. But while most games that try to tap into the metal aesthetic go for goofy self-parody and over-the-top ultraviolence, Tormentum - Dark Sorrow instead uses it to explore themes of morality in extreme circumstances. Shallowly, I'll admit; the game gives you Kant's "Kingdom of Ends" prinicpal right off the bat and if you remember to follow it every time you're faced with a choice you're guaranteed a good ending. But it's great to see the genre's ideas used for something other than pure power fantasy. 

This may be the only game where you watch the ending credits for it's own sake, by the way.

24483421.review:
Though billed as a point and click adventure, Tormemtum has little in common with the genre staples like Broken Sword or Monkey Island. Rarely, if ever, will the items you collect and jam into the infinite confines of your cloak have to be assembled together into some wacky contraption that conveniently bypasses the obstacle of the moment. Exit your cell and you find a shard of mirror. On the next screen over, you find a broken mirror in need of some reflective shards. Explore your cell and excavate a jeweled eye from one of the skeletons. On the same screen as the broken mirror is a statue with empty sockets for eyes.

There’s rarely a hidden motive for collecting items and everything has a clear purpose, so puzzling comes in to form of, well, puzzles. And herein starts the unwelcome comparisons to the hidden object genre. Kind of, anyway, because as a genre, it’s moved away from presenting random screen full of jumble and asking you to pick out three blue telephones and a heron yet has someone still kept its name. I mean, I don’t know what else to call it without having to start using the world casual unironically, and I’m far too sober to attempt that.

To be clear, the kinds of object searching both genres are famed for are nonexistent in Tormentum. You rarely have to junk-sort or pixel hunt as hotspots are highlighted by a flickering aura of light. Instead, the game turns to the logic puzzles that have evolved in their place, which doesn’t have to be a bad thing. You can obtain a jewel by lowering the right corpse-laden cages chronicled in a desperate sketch found outside your cell. Piecing together the broken mirror asks you to manipulate rays of light to open a passageway further into the nightmare-choked castle. Fixing a series of fuses and collecting the tattooed remains of a skeleton summons an electrified ghost you can help put to rest. It’s either that or spend more time taunting the giant needle-toothed worm who jealously guards your rat chum’s jail.

Read full review here // http://www.honestgamers.com/12504/pc/tormentum-dark-sorrow/review.html

24258476.review:
刚刚一周目结束，从六个方面来说说这款游戏。

语言 - 全流程基本没有发现生僻词汇，所以即使英语不算精通，也可以放心入正。

谜题 - 整体难度偏低，卡关情况很少。虽然谜题形式较丰富，一定程度弥补了难度上的不足，但总是少了一点令玩家惊叹“哈！原来还可以这样！”的巧妙设计（比如机械迷城里那个必须通过故意答错简单题目才能通过的老风扇）。

剧情 - 相比解谜，“选择”在游戏中所占的比重更大一些，这也是本作的一大亮点。随流程推进自动存档，玩家无法通过S/L进行悔棋操作。缺乏思考的选择可能会在无意中毁掉你想要的结局，本人的best end就不经意间毁于游戏初期某次不经大脑的习惯性按钮，发现时已是流程最末、悔之晚矣。

画面 - 整体风格可以看出受到了“死后世界”系列作品的影响。暗黑系的画面有很强的艺术性，其中一处教堂内竟设置了四十余幅不同主题的画作，有限的空间被作者的心意塞得满满当当。相较某些终日打着情怀幌子行吸金之实的制作者，本作的制作团队虽然只有三个人，但用心程度令人佩服。

流程 - 偏短，稍有解谜游戏常识的玩家可在四小时左右完成游戏一周目，40元的价格此时看来就略微小贵了，还是推荐加了愿望单，打折时再购入吧。

总体来说，精致有余，巧妙不足，但仍是解谜爱好者不容错过的一款游戏。8/10。

Beautiful? Yes. Dark? Yes. Surreal? Yep.

Fun? Debateable. Good Story? Not really. Deep? Hard no.


Tormentum has beautiful visuals with an excellent soundtrack but a rather weak story and overall gameplay experience. I think the potential of this game is what had me the most disappointed. 

If they hired an industry vet that specialized in Adventure game design and a writer to capitalize on the Lovecraftian/Geiger inspired atmosphere, this game had the potential to become an instant cult classic. As it stands right now, it feels more like playing an interactive museum. 

Also the moral choice system doesn't really fit anywhere and is pretty half baked. Just to give you an idea, before I even knew there was a moral choice system in the game I accidentally performed an 'evil' choice when I was figuring out a puzzle. Despite making 'good' choices the rest of the game, the one action overwrote all other choices and I was sent to hell. In other words, it doesn't average out your choices. You are either evil, even if your actions are grey, or you're perfect and you reach sainthood. I would have expected a purgatory or some kind of grey ending but nothing like that exists. You have a 90% chance of becoming Hitler and a 10% chance of becoming Mother Theresa.

I have high hopes for the team and what they accomplished with a $11,000 USD budget is incredible. I look forward to their next offering and will likely contribute to their next crowdfunding campaign.

From my Blog about this game:

You died. Now you have to escape your cell, traverse a wasteland filled with strange creatures, solve puzzles and make choices. Your afterlife depends on your actions, are you going to heaven or to hell? Make your choice. This is the overall story of the game Tormentum: Dark Sorrow. It’s made by Oh Noo Studios, a three man team with ambitions of grandeur. The team based the world and artwork on the paintings of famous artists H.R. Giger and Zdzislaw Beksinski. H.R. Giger was a Swiss surrealist most famous for being part of the team that won Alien their Academy Award for design.  All of his artwork is on display in his own museum in Zurich. His style of artwork usually melds man and machine in what he called biomechanical. Zdzislaw Beksinski was from Poland and worked more on dystopian surrealism in a more environmental for his earlier works. For his later works he focused more on dulling the background and unnatural lighting on the subject of the painting. In true dystopian fashion he was murdered in his home for refusing to loan his caretaker’s son $100.

While the style of H.R. Giger and Zdzislaw Beksinski are more dark fantasy and gothic, I feel like the themes and style of the puzzles is way more steampunk. The mechanics are simple, it’s a point and click. Some of the puzzles are challenging but there are notes throughout the game that will make things make a little more sense. You might get stuck, you might get frustrated, hell you might even give up once or twice, but the beauty of this game will draw you in and hold you till you lose your sanity. I mean until you finish the game. For those of you like myself there are achievements and there are different endings so there is replayability. I don’t really want to give away the game but I would like to talk about my favourite part of the game.

My favourite part of this game is the cathedral. A blind old man has been trapped in this cathedral for…well I’m not sure how long he’s been there. All this time he’s been painting. There are dozens of paintings and the old man gives you paint and a brush to fix up 30 of them. But he also has a pet, this pet is kind of a dick, instead of fixing up 30 painting you can destroy 3. In both my playthroughs I spent a solid hour picking and deciding which painting I would restore. The art is amazing, for a three man team I don’t know how they were able to create such an awe inspiring visuals. Everything from hanging tree’s to tortured souls you will find plenty of artwork you want to as backgrounds.

A short and simple, yet very beautiful point and click adventure.

Combine that with the soundtrack that perfectly captures each screen you pass and you get a very atmospheric experience. I hope that at some point, they will release the soundtrack.

But yes, like mentioned, I believe the story is a take on the Divine Comedy, with the main protagonist taking a journey of redemption through his personal hell. Things aren't always what they seem.

23248849.review:
Tormentum - Dark Sorrow was an amazing experience for me. I loved every minute of it and was a bit sad when it was over.

[h1]Game Summary[/h1]

In Tormentum, you play as a hooded figure that has lost all his memories, save the memory of a dream of a strange statue on a hill. He awakens in captivity and is told he is to be punished for crimes he doesn't remember commiting. The game follows his escape and journey to the the hill from his dreams, in the hopes of restoring his memory. Along the way, he meets many strange characters, visits terrifying landscapes, and is presented with moral choices that shape his jouney, and eventually, his destiny.

[h1]Breakdown[/h1]

[b]Graphics:[/b] The art style was what caught my attention initally and is arguably the strongest asset the game. The characters, set pieces, and landscapes are all so alien, yet disturbingly beautiful. Unlocking a door or opening a new area was exciting, not just because I was progressing through the game, but because I would be rewarded with new and beautiful art that would leave me staring with a sense or wonder and horror rolled into one.

[b]Music/Sound:[/b] The music is haunting and when combined with the art made for a really good atmosphere. The sound effects are well done, from opening of chests to the squelching of blood to the soft growl of a monstrous creature, each one felt solid and immersive.

[b]Gameplay/Mechanics:[/b] The moral choices, while interesting, is probably where my biggest complaint with the game comes from. It was obvious in most cases which choice was good and which was evil, which I did like, because I never worried that I would make a choice that would result in an outcome I hadn't intended. However, there is no grey area: one wrong choice automatically gets you the bad ending, even if all the other choices you made were considered good. Because of this, there was almost no motivation for you to make the evil choices(except one of them where the evil choice saves you time). Not to mention the fact that (minor spoiler) [spoiler]you steal objects from people that call you "friend" and kill several creatures[/spoiler].

[b]UI/Controls:[/b] The UI is simple and minimalistic: you have an inventory bag in the lower right corner for items you find and a notepad in the lower left that copies any puzzle hints and intsructions you come across. Arrows on the sides of screens and door icons clearly highlight where you can go, so you never feel at a loss as to where you can explore. Your cursor changes to a skeletal hand when you can interact with something and occasionally a soft glow emanates from interactive objects as well. All these elements did little to interfere with the art, which is good, as the art is one of the strongest points of the game.

Controls are simple and easy to pick up: you click things. That's it. I didn't have any trouble clicking exactly what I wanted to click,

 Overall, the UI annd controls, while not innovative or particularly engrossing, was well excuted and functioned adequately.

[b]Story:[/b] I felt story to be the weakest part of the game; not bad, but it could have been better.

The characters, while beautiful and interesting, aren't deep and left me wanting to find out more about them, but with no recourse to do so. Other than the moral choices, your own character's personality and story doesn't develop at all either. You're trying to reach that statue from your dream. That's it for the whole game. There isn't any way for the protaginst to express himself, short of deciding if he should senselessly murder someone or not.


Dispite the few points I didn't like, I still highly recommend this game. The wording of the title, to me, suggests the possibility of a sequel, One that I would absolutely play if it comes out.

[h1] An Artist's Attempt At a Game[/h1]

As a huge fan of Lovecraftian horror I have always loved games with grotesquely beautiful art styles and disturbing storylines, which was why I chose to throw myself at this game the moment I got home today instead of doing work. And now almost three hours later, I have come to an uneasy conclusion.

That I cannot wholeheartedly recommend this game. 

The reason behind my conclusion is actually very simple and can be summarized into a single sentence: 

[b] Beautiful artworks doth not a good game make. [/b] 

Yes, the artwork was absolutely exquisite, and each scene is breath-taking in own its way. The atmosphere was very nice and the unique design of monsters and characters kept my fingers hovering around F12 while secretly hoping for even more interesting ones to come.  But this doesn't hide the fact the game is simply lacking in so many features that it cannot be called a "good game" but rather "a good set of illustrations", and this is very frustrating as this game could have been so much more. 

The game, having excelled in the artwork department, unfortunately falls flat on story, character design and puzzles, and here is why. 

[b] Story [/b]:

I dont want to spoil the story here so i'm just going to say this:

[b] The game's moral choice system is so bland that at times it really just feels like picking between a lettuce and a cabbage [/b] , as you really wouldn't care less about "that character whom i have zero knowledge of". There are no tear-jerking moments and heart-torn decisions, just "here is this character do you want to kill him? oh what you do? well you're just plain evil ain't you?" Or "here's this action that will kill that character over there, wanna do it? Oh you don't? well ain't you a saint", which is so hilariously simple that one almost wishes real-life was that easy.


[b] Characters [/b]:

Design? Beautiful and unique
Depth? ZERO.

You'll get to meet a lot of characters during your playthrough, however you'll get to know pretty much none of them. A lot of them seems to promise very interesting back-stories (The Maiden on the Throne, the Torturing Knight) , but nope, you won't get to see them, instead you only get to stare at them longingly through your computer screen and imagine what mesmerising tales they could have told. 


[b] Puzzles [/b]:

[b] Variety does not equal to quality [/b]

Yes the game has A LOT of puzzles, but they are really just a re-make of your usual "point and click" advanture game puzzles: From sliding blocks to rotating discs, its got them all. 

And the puzzles are really not challenging at all. 


So overall i'm just going to say this. Had this not been a game but just a artwork set i would have gladly paid just as much and recommended it to all my friends. 

But it's a game, and interactive pictures are not games, no matter how beautiful they are :)

„Tormentum – Dark Sorrow“ has taken me on a strange trip to a creepy world of sorrow, where pain and misery become alive to punish me for my sins. The obscure story is mature as it confronts you with haunting moral questions/decisions as they not only affect your life but also the lives of others. The impressive text passages complete the atmospherical immersion. A very unique experience I never had before playing a video game !

С учетом того, что локации в основном полностью не помещаются в экран, соответственно, приходится мышкой «пролистывать» их влево и вправо. Но герой при этом всегда стоит на одном, заранее предусмотренном месте локации. Сюда же можно отнести отсутствие высоких разрешений в игре (и вообще каких бы то ни было разрешений). Можно включить игру на полный экран, но черные полосы по краям монитора никуда не уйдут, т.е. настройка «Полный экран» только растягивает изображение, при этом делая его мыльным, а на деле сама игра была сделана в низком разрешении.

Другой момент – излишняя простота и очевидность игры в плане прохождения. Здесь есть множество пазлов, но сколько-то ощутимо сложных нет. При этом на любой пазл, который мог стать действительно сложным, можно найти в игре подсказку (читайте: полное решение пазла). Взаимодействие находимых предметов с интерактивными объектами на локации – тоже очевидное, но здесь есть небольшой плюс в копилку игры: все решения в игре понятны с точки зрения логики. Т.е. здесь не будет такого, что нужно выманить кошку из дома, скотчем нацепить на нее диктофон, чтобы она вернулась в дом и записала сверхсекретные переговоры, а потом выманить ее обратно и забрать диктофон (пример из Secret Files: Tunguska).

Сюжет в игре на первых порах кажется интересным и занятным. Но когда проходишь игру, то раскрывается вся суть того, что происходило, и сюжет кажется уже не таким занятным, а чересчур обыденным. Лучше, если бы авторы оставили недомолвку, а не раскрывали бы перед игроком все карты. Тем более, что это получилось у них на поверку «не очень». Отдельный разговор – диалоги. По всей видимости, разработчики сами писали их (все-таки имеем дело с инди-проектом), от того диалоги либо чересчур пафосные, либо банальны настолько, что возникает такое ощущение, будто это реплики персонажей из рассказа, написанного каким-нибудь Ваней Петровым из первого «Б» класса.

Действительно порадовала только некоторая вариативность в игре, а именно: за игру встретится с десяток ситуаций, когда надо будет сделать выбор, кому отдать какой-нибудь предмет, или убить существо али отпустить его на волю. В зависимости от выбора, сделанного игроком, предусмотрены две различные концовки. Причем я рекомендую вам при первом прохождении не подсматривать в гайды, а принимать решения самостоятельно. Если захотите собрать все достижения, то собирайте их, уже начиная со второго прохождения. В зависимости от того, как прошло для вас в плане судьбоносных решений первое прохождение, все достижения можно будет собрать за 2-3 прохождения. Мне пришлось проходить игру трижды. Впрочем, особого труда это не составило, ибо, раз запомнив последовательность действий, далее игра проходится спокойно за 40-60 минут. Собственно, игра и так коротка. Разработчики пишут о 4-6 часах прохождения. Но это каким слоупоком надо быть, чтобы настолько долго задержаться в игре? Мое первое прохождение заняло 3 часа с натяжкой.

Подводя итог: игра моментами действительно привлекает. Но сложностей при прохождении никаких не вызывает, думать практически не заставляет, проходится на одном дыхании и также быстро забывается. Можно поиграть, если вы фанат квестов, но стоит ли покупать ее за полную стоимость? Я лично считаю, что нет. Лучше дождаться, когда она появится на акции. Если что, я предупреждал вас.

21690834.review:
Tormentum - Dark Sorrow

Мрак, пустота, боль и страдания – такими покажутся грядущие перспективы этой игры. Полное тьмы и забвения путешествие в явно неоднозначном мире. Попадаем в него уже словно с обречением, в качестве героя, который не знает ничего ни о себе, ни о своём прошлом. Ни имён, ни историй - ровным счётом ничего. 

Короткое пребывание в игре запомнится контрастным миром визуального кошмара. Буквально всё напитано ужасом и всевозможными мелкими деталями насыщенной этим атмосферой. В тот же самый момент это усугубляется тяжестью музыкального сопровождения - давление «тяжёлой нотой». В мире этого приключенческого квеста можно найти погружение в бездну самого себя. Предстоит бродить по здешним локациям в поисках того, чем бы «поживиться», что взять и куда-нибудь пристроить. Однако, всевозможные подсказки, порой до банального документа с полным решением головоломки, не вызовут ни малейшего затруднения. Назвать квест особо сложным, непонятным или долгим - просто невозможно. Каждый «ключ», найденный в игре, в прямом смысле имеет форму, которая пойдёт только к одной «замочной скважине». Запоминается именно мир очаровательного мрака. Помимо основного занятия - «тыканья» предметами инвентаря, можно насладиться краткими историями местных обитателей. По сути, всё завязано на осмыслении простого решения – убить или спасти. Однако, не все «добрые» дела будут такими уж и добрыми. Этот факт порождает большой плюс игры – возможность выбора и, как следствие, факт получения от этого различных концовок.

За основу нашего нахождения в игре взяты постулаты – вопросы, которые персонаж задаёт в начале путешествия. Обидно правда за то, что хоть одна ошибка, и ваши ответы изменяться, а их, и так понятно, можно будет узнать только при завершении игры. Порой не всегда легко различить «добро» и «зло», один неверный выбор портит вашу «статистику» перед высшим судом. Забавным фактом остаётся ещё и то, что герой, по сути, не имеет лица, даже неизвестно какое существо скрывается за пеленой капюшона.
Мир персонажей здесь довольно разнообразный - первым встретившимся будет крыса, в дальнейшем это будут изуродованные в тяжёлой мере люди, а также различные монстры, охраняющие локации от нашего вторжения до поры до времени. Повстречаются враждующие взгляды на предметы, которые можно отдать только одному. Порой именно моральная сторона сыграет свою роль.

Ни для кого ни секрет, что за основу локаций взяты работы самого Ганса Рудольфа Гигера. Многим он запомнился работой над образом «Чужого», однако работы, которые предстают взору в игре, явно заслуживают не меньшего внимания. Все места, в которых предстоит побывать, заполнены мельчайшими деталями, которым явно стоит уделить время для большего наполнения и погружения в мир. Если взять всю прелесть мрачной картины игры и добавить, усиливающих атмосферу кошмарного места, композиций, то получается приятное путешествие на небольшое количество времени.

В заключении хотелось бы сказать пару слов о финале данного квеста. Игра в целом получилась довольно удачной, но конец немножко не пришёлся мне по душе. Явно не хватает возможностей. Банальный исход из двух концов был небольшим разочарованием – либо возносишься за свои труды, либо проваливаешься ещё глубже, но зато получаешь ответы на мучающие вопросы при любом исходе. В сущности, как уже и было отмечено ранее, всё завязано на выборе между «добром» и «злом», а ведь выборов было не так и мало за всё время, ничего нейтрального не будет, к сожалению. Герой тот, кто он есть, и это лишь очередной шанс переосмысления жизненного пути.

Спасибо разработчикам за труды, это определённо удачный проект, а также интересное начинание немногочисленных игр подобного жанра. Было над чем поразмыслить, погрузиться в мысли о своей жизни и о своих моральных выборах в прошлом. Каждый вынесет свой смысл, почувствует осадок внутри…

You already dead or... still alive. You know the correct answer?...

Habe das Spiel aufgrund der ansprechenden düsteren Atmosphäre und des gelungenen Stils gekauft.  Die vielen positiven Bewertungen bei Steam haben ihr übriges getan und mich nun auch dazu veranlasst diese negative Rezension zu schreiben.

 Im Spiel musste ich  schnell feststellen, dass abgesehen vom gelungenen  Stil wenig geboten wird. Die meisten der wirklich guten handgezeichneten Hintergründe sieht man bereits in der Screenshotvorschau im Shop, wodurch im Spiel selbst wenig neues geboten wird.

 Die Rätsel sind wirklich sehr simpel und gerade mit den im Spiel gebotenen Hinweisen extrem einfach und schnell zu lösen.
 Technisch bleibt zu sagen: Es gibt keine wirklichen Animationen aufgrund des geringen Budgets. Ebenso ist die Auflösung und Bildschirmausfüllung doch sehr dürftig und im 16:9 und 21:10 Format mit großen schwarzen Balken an allen Bildschrimseiten versehen. Positiv ist der düstere passende Soundtrack. 
Es gibt keine Sprachvertonung und die Dialoge sind auch nicht sonderlich gut geschrieben. Hier wird für meinen Geschmack eindeutig durch den besonderen Grafikstil über das eigentliche Spiel hinweggetäuscht.

 Die Spielzeit ist mit 3-4 Stunden auch äußerst gering. 
Das Spiel bietet ein paar Entscheidungen, welche aber keine besonders tiefgreifenden Folgen bieten und eher aufgezwungen wirken.  

 Für die 12 Euro Vollpreis ist das Spiel aus diesen Gründen nicht zu empfehlen. Maximal würde ich 2-3 Euro dafür ausgeben und auf jeden Fall empfehlen die Demo vorher auszuprobieren.
 Ich selbst habe das Spiel noch vor der 2 Stunden Zeitmarke umgetauscht, da die Enttäuschung doch sehr überwogen hat und bereits mehr als die Hälfte des Spiels damit abgeschlossen war. 

Fazit: Keine Kaufempfehlung zum Vollpreis. Für Freunde des Grafikstils ist das Spiel unter der 5 Euro Marke vielleicht noch interessant und optimalerweise schaut man sich vorher keine Screenshots oder Videos zum Spiel an, da diese bereits einen Großteil des interessanten Inhalts ausmachen. 21370213.review:
More a work of H.R. Giger inspired art than a game.

The visuals are heavily inspired by their source material, but also stand on their own with their own unique touch.  Many of the images in the game would serve well as a poster or portrait in the home of one so inclined towards the style.  The music does a great job of enhancing the somber, alien landscape and its equally alien inhabitants.

The writing is passable, serving to push the events of the story and game along, but nothing that will stick in your head when you're done playing.  The story, likewise, exists but is not worthy of remark.

It's a shame that while the art and style of the game are clearly inspired, gameplay is less so.  Puzzles in the game rely heavily on generic puzzle tropes (slider puzzles, circuit puzzles) and commonly repeat themselves.  I personally would have preferred puzzles that interacted more directly with the fascinating world this game strove so hard to create.  The game is also heavily dependent on alignment based decisions, but these choices are so black/white in nature they engender no internal discourse, save for which achievement you are aiming to unlock.

For the price, those inclined towards Giger's style will find enjoyment in this game, and I'm glad I got to experience it despite its flaws.  Those looking for a creepy game that better incorporates puzzles into its mythos may want to look towards a title like Fran Bow.

It's an okay game. Not bad, not great, but okay. It's got great artwork reminiscent of H. R. Giger, and practically every screen looks like it could be the cover of a metal album. There are a few puzzles here and there, but they're pretty simple unless you're just really bad at puzzles.

However, the things that really make this game fall flat are that it's far too short (easily beatable in under an hour), it's too linear (in that there is a set path, and there are a few puzzles that you can do in any order you choose, but you'll always wind up going to the same limited places within the game, not to mention there's no actual risk of failure), and that any choices you make are kind of pointless.

Despite having multiple choices to make throughout the game, there are only two possible endings, and if you make even one bad choice, it doesn't matter how many good choices you make, you're automatically locked into the bad ending. Based on the endings, this tells me the writer intended for the game to have a very black and white view of morality, no gray area whatsoever, no justification for why you did an action that you did, just "if you did even one bad thing, that makes you a horrible person who doesn't deserve a good ending". I believe an easy way to sum up the problem with this so-called "morality" system is to say that it's a talented art students attempt at writing a story that deals with what should be a complex and possibly complicated topic.

Overall, it has the potential to be really great, but the linearity and illusion of choice that results in one of two lackluster endings rather than having various possibilities, in addition to the incredibly short playtime and basic puzzles results in an experience that's cool at first glance, but kind of disappointing when you actually go through with it.

21089783.review:
Tormentum: Dark Sorrow is an interactive collection of Heavy Metal magazine covers. Harkening back to the glory days of Frank Frazetta and badass Iron Maiden album covers, your main driving force for progression is to advance to the next scene and see what madness the artists have pulled from the twisted depths of their minds. There are some real simple “find the object” and logic puzzles blocking your path as well as a Lovecraftian narrative with branching paths, but the game's main draw is viewing the beautifully grotesque and unsettling.

  You navigate the world of Tormentum as a cloaked, hooded figure who is taken to a castle against his will and locked in a cage. You have a dirty ratman cellmate nearby, and a knight in spiky, black armor is really keen on torturing you and the other prisoners. You make an escape by clicking around the environment until you uncover a random assortment of adventure game puzzle pieces and match Key Object A with Lock Object A. Throughout the game you'll also be presented with fairly standard puzzles to solve: slide the squares to make a picture, find the paper to decipher the symbols, memory match card games, Guess Who, etc. None of the riddles are notably difficult or obscure, but that's to the game's benefit. They feel more like brain exercises than anything. You'll get a small serotonin rush for solving them, but they're not brain twisters that will have you beating your head against a wall or rushing for a walkthrough. This keeps the momentum going and the scenery changing, which again is why you should be playing the game.

  As you journey through the game's hellscape, you're presented with some binary choices that will affect your ending. Do you help a mad jester murder a caged woman in exchange for a needed key? You could enact some sweet revenge on your jailer by impaling him, but is that “right”? The best one involves busywork dusting off a blind man's paintings, which can be bypassed by siding with his cat-monster pet/thing and slashing his life's work out of their frames to get the blueprints you need. I dusted the paintings, because again the game is all about the art. On the whole the story, taken as a standard piece of fiction, is rather inconsequential and a bit nonsensical, though that's not entirely a negative as it adds to the nightmare quality of the game. Shocker: it would be right at home as a comic inside of a Heavy Metal magazine...

  Viewing Tormentum as an art book with light adventure game elements, there's only a few sore points of which to be critical. Most jarring is when the art isn't good; scattered amidst the frame-worthy set pieces are mundane, functional insert shots like when you have to pick up a key or a note. These just stick out as amateurish brush strokes in comparison to the rest of the game. The pacing is off; the first area is a nice tutorial, teaching you the basics of inventory management and puzzle solving. The game then ramps up in complexity, asking you to solve puzzles that affect objects several screens away and navigating some tricky, missable areas. Then the final third basically boils down to a few simple screens and obvious objects to find and use. The game isn't about “challenge”, but the last areas feel unfinished/rushed. Finally, there's a puzzle toward the end of the game that involves reading a music sheet and playing notes on a piano. I won't spoil the puzzle or solution outright, but it makes zero logical sense when you figure it out.

  I'm not a huge fan of adventure games, but I really enjoyed playing through Tormentum: Dark Sorrow. Every screen could be a month on a dark fantasy calendar, and exploring those paintings by clicking around isn't too bad, either. Throw in some simple but satisfying puzzles, and sure... it's a good game. It's good enough that at the end credits, while some cheesy metal music was playing, I made sure to hit “F12” on my keyboard and now I have a new badass desktop background.

21072314.review:
Oozing with gore and morbidity, Tormentum - Dark Sorrow is an engrossing point and click adventure that you're sure to remember for years to come. The game itself is seething with hellish nightmarescapes, and venomously dripping with macabre dialogue; a far more tortured choice compared to many of the point and clicks available on the market today. Make no mistake, this title is not for those who may get depressed easily, as it deals with some heavy subject matter and it confronts those dark, ghastly thoughts that linger in the back of our minds; forcing us to think about our life choices, and what may be waiting for us in the afterlife.

Hands down, the main focus of Tormentum is its eerily captivating artwork. The artists did one hell of an amazing job merging the soft pastels and hazy dream-like features of Zdzislaw Beksinski's work with the harsh, alien architecture of H.R. Giger. If it weren't completely impossible, I'd go as far to say that both of these renowned surrealist artists collaborated and contributed the art straight to the game. The massive amounts of detail that has been put into the artwork alone more than makes Tormentum worth the full selling price, artists as talented as the ones who worked on this title deserve high recognition and I firmly believe that true art should never be undersold. The screenshots that you will see on the store page are just a faint few of the 70+ cadaverous hand-painted expanses that you will wander across, and there are numerous devils to encounter. The entire world that has been created for Tormentum feels overwhelmingly larger than you are.

Coupling the awe inspiring artwork is a dark, brooding soundtrack. I sincerely wish that it was for sale on Steam, as I would purchase it in a heartbeat. There was actually one part of the game, near this giant tower, that I enjoyed the music so much that I cranked my speakers, left my computer and proceeded to do housework while just listening to the audio. It's rare for me to enjoy a game soundtrack this deeply, but I would actually put Tormentum's score on a regular playlist; right along side some Bethlehem, Velvet Acid Christ and Burzum. The ominous, ambient hymns bring an entire new dimension to the art style that is displayed within the game, and they really suck the gamer in while refusing to let go.

So, what is this game actually about? Sadly, I can't delve far into the story without spoiling it completely; I will say that you are a man, wandering the huge realm of Tormentum in search of a way out. Along the way you must face tough choices, all of which will ultimately matter in the end. The character that you are playing has no more knowledge than you do, and vica versa; this is much akin to plots like that of Stasis and Sanitarium. You will learn more about the hellish world that you're traversing through by reading notes and speaking with the many interactive beings within the game. Many of these fiends are quite forlorn and profound with their dialogue, which is reminiscent of The Divine Comedy by Dante. As usual, it will all make the most sense once the game has reached completion.

Tormentum - Dark Sorrow is a completely stunning macabre point and click game that will appeal to a niche audience. Art enthusiasts will absolutely love this game for its stunning in-depth visuals, audiophiles will love it for the superbly creepy soundtrack, and fans of both will completely fall in morbid love. While the story isn't anything to rave about, it will strike a chord with fans of literature along the lines of The Divine Comedy (Dante's Inferno). The only real fault that I could possibly find with Tormentum is how short it is. I finished 3 full playthroughs in roughly 6 hours, with my initial run clocking in at about 3 and a half hours. That being said, I just can't gush and go on about this title enough. It's absolutely the best point and click experience I've ever had, but then again I love H.R. Giger, Zdzislaw Beksinski, Dante's Inferno and dark ambient music. If you're a fan of any of the aforementioned things, do not hesitate to throw your money down on this twisted nightmare.

The puzzles are simple and amusing (not what I would consider challenging or frustrating), but add an extra layer that tends to augment the story and world.  This is a positive aspect in my opinion since the game is a work emphasizing morality and consequence of choice.  While the choice tree is binary in nature, the end results are less so, and choices cause the story to 'ripple' in different ways as you progress.

I would certainly describe this as a casual game, and this is supported by its well-considered design that a) does not require the player to manually save the game and b) does not allow the player to get 'stuck' and have to restart.

The story was interesting and, to my surprise, actually managed to keep a few tidbits hidden from me until the very end.  Speaking of which, the ending (at least to me) was above average and included an interesting slant.

All Steam achievements are able to be obtained within two or three playthroughs, each of which get progressively faster since the player knows what choices they intend to make ahead of time.  This is why I would recommend focusing on playing the game 'naturally' on the first playthrough, instead of immediately focusing on achievement farming.  You will likely get more enjoyment out of it that way.

For some (primarily those intrigued with the art and atmosphere), the game will be worth the full price.  For others who are still interested but edgy about its short duration, pick it up during a sale.  You will still enjoy it.

Overall, Tormentum is definitely a recommended game for casual play.

20419079.review:
This game is so deserving of the "overwhelmingly positive" label it has when I am writing this. It tells the story of an unknown, unseen character robed in a tattered, hooded cloak. He/she/it is captured by some militia and left in a castle to be tortured. From there you need to escape and find out who you are, all the time meeting the most bizarre characters and creatures I have seen in fantasy.

Firstly, this is a Point & Click game. I found the idea of these dull BEFORE I picked this game up during the Steam sale (whatever the price it is now it is probably worth it). It makes up for the lack of normal gameplay (i.e. moving a character around, regular animation, etc) by having some of the most macabre, horrific, gruesome yet beautiful and astounding scenes I have ever seen, accompanied each time with unique atmospheric music which at times makes me think of latter day Burzum. They are inspired by the painter Zdzisław Beksiński, H.R. Giger and I find the atmosphere remeniscent of a Lovecraftian nightmare at times.

Gameplay is somewhat typical of P&C games: each scene presents you with various things to interact with, items to collect and puzzles to solve. Solving puzzles is the key to moving from various areas and the puzzles are not too challenging or frustrating. You won't need a walkthrough if you just stop, sit back and think. Some are even remeniscent of the games you'd find on a smartphone game.

There are also a few moral choices. They are not all black and white either. Your choices decide the ending and the ending does have a twist that admittedly made me go, "wow ok, this didn't occur to me". 

Replay value is not especially the highest BUT this isn't a game made for gameplay. It's for storytelling and immersion. I will play it regularly just to immerse myself again in this eldritch realm. In this respect it is perfect. 
Yeah, really this game is 10/10. I see no fault at all.

If you choose to buy this game please also consider buying it directly from the developers website. They sell it but also include other options such as a high quality book of all the artwork and some other articles. The art is really beautiful and I think worthy of having in a book.

10/10, worth your time if you enjoy dark fantasy, morbid imagery and Lovecraft style fantasy.

Главное, что привлекает в Tormentum: Dark Sorrow - это замечательные визуальная и звуковая составляющие. Игра создает шикарную атмосферу тревожности и безысходности. Как сказано в описании, окончательный вид Tormentum’а возник, помимо всего прочего, под впечатлением от Demon’s Souls. И действительно, Tormentum отчасти напоминает атмосферой, а местами дизайном и звуком, игры серии Souls, что я считаю плюсом.
Понравилась и некоторая неоднозначность решений, принимаемых в игре, когда любое действие с одной стороны может являться положительным, а с другой - отрицательным.
[spoiler]В самом начале перед игроком встает выбор, опустить клетку с крысой, или позволить узнику упасть на колья и умереть. Тогда этот выбор казался однозначным: выпустить - хорошо, убить - плохо. Но когда позже по сюжету игрок оказывается в доме этого пленника и попадает в подвал, выясняется, что крысы там жестоко пытают людей, и сделанный выбор уже не кажется таким уж правильным.[/spoiler]
Но на этом чисто положительные моменты, на мой взгляд, заканчиваются. И начинаются спорные. Одним из них являются задачки. Они довольно простенькие, но этот факт можно считать как за плюс, так и за минус, в зависимости от предпочтений игрока. Лично мне всегда не хватает терпения долго ломать голову над задачкой, и быстро возникает желание подсмотреть в прохождении, потому излишняя легкость не показалась мне минусом. Но любителям поломать голову над задачкой тут делать нечего. Стоит также отметить, что задачки не всегда логичны, но это беда многих квестов.
Главный, на мой взгляд, спорный момент опять же касается выборов. За свое прохождение плохой выбор был сделан мной дважды. Так как для хорошей концовки можно поступить «неправильно» лишь один раз, концовка у меня была плохая. И это казалось жутко нелогичным. [spoiler]В конце, когда перечисляют все мои поступки, получилось, что друг за другом идут хорошие дела, а в итоге судья заявляет, что, дескать, видишь, как много ты грешил и т.п. Смотрится реально странно.[/spoiler] К тому же стоит отметить, что выборы здесь отмечаются картинками, а потому надо быть внимательней. [spoiler]Например, в моменте с убийством/освобождением крысы: картинка №1 показывает открывающуюся клетку, №2 - опускающуюся. Мне показалось, что открыть - значит отпустить, а спустить - значит выбросить в яму. В итоге все оказалось наоборот, и решение, соответственно, было принято неверно. Но это уже чисто моя придирка.	[/spoiler]
В целом, игра вышла достойной. После прохождения я не жалею ни о потраченных деньгах, ни о затраченном времени. Однако цепляющей я ее назвать не могу. Сюжет и концовка, хоть и неплохие, во многом подкачали, и особенно впечатление испортило 	[spoiler]перечисление моих «грехов» в конце [/spoiler]. Кроме того, игрушка довольно короткая. Но, несмотря ни на что, однозначно рекомендую к прохождению.

L'ambiance est extraordinaire, grâce notamment à sont univers torturé servi par un design unique qui, sans être irréprochable est tout de même vraiment bien fichu, ainsi que sa bande son minimaliste impeccablement immersive. On peut certes regrèter un manque de finesse et de détails lors des zoom sur les différents éléments du décors mais ne soyons pas trop gourmants, nous sommes sur une petite production après tout et puis au fond, cela rajouterait presque un petit côté sale très raccord avec l'objectif de Tormentum, nous mettre mal à l'aise !
Les énigmes sont toutes assez simples et ce n'est pas forcément un mauvais point ; Passez des heures de brainstorming sur des énigmes trop farfelues peut facilement écoeurer le joueur et faire décrocher les moins persévérants. On avance donc à un bon rythme, presque trop vite toutes fois, mais l'intérêt du jeu est ailleurs : l'intrigue !
Tout au long de l'aventure, notre prisonnier amnésique tentera de s'évader du cauchemard dans lequel il s'est réveillé, enfermé dans une cage. Pour ce faire, il sera confronté à des choix, tous lourds de conséquences pour sa destinée.
Au final, Tormentum s'inscrit comme le récit de l'âme humaine, déchirée entre envies et regrets, sur un fond légèrement philosophique sans jamais vous donner mal à la tête. On lui reprochera cependant d'être extrêmement court mais l'aventure vaut grandement le détours, surtout si l'on considère la rejouabilité du titre pour réussir le dénouement parfait.
Vous êtes prévenus, bon jeu...

Yanıbaşımızdaki kafesin içinde bir tutsak daha olduğunu ve onun aksine kim olduğumuzu ve buraya nasıl geldiğimizi bilemeyecek kadar afallamış bir vaziyette bulunduğumuzu fark ediyoruz. [b]TLDR:[/b] an aesthetically beautiful, simple, but short game with many flaws. Recommend a buy only if discounted or if you really like the aesthetic.

[b]NOTE:[/b] I actually played the game for about three hours, I have less on record because I was not online when playing.

[b]THE GOOD:[/b]
The game is, simply put, beautiful. Each area, character and object is very well designed and every scene would not look out of place as the cover of a metal album.

[b]THE BAD:[/b]
The game is very short. I have managed two full playthroughs in three hours, the first one carried out at an extremely leisurely pace, especially consider I am not at all good at adventure/puzzle games. Most puzzles are fairly simple and with a relatively obvious solution. In the entire playthrough there was only one point where I found myself stumped (and even then it turned out I already had the item I needed and I had simply missed a detail in its description earlier). The game also has a heavy moral choice element, which is not everyone’s cup of tea.

[b][u]WARNING – HEAVY ENDGAME SPOILERS FOLLOW[/b][/u]



[b]THE UGLY:[/b]
While the game has a marked black/white moral choice element, the “good” choice (i.e. the morally upright choice) is not always clear. Examples are the fact that it is moral to spare prison guards (even though their main/only activity is the torture of prisoners) and it is correct to give the powerful artefact to the mysterious mage that basically tells you “I will not abuse its power, like pinky swear” (he is telling the truth, but when making the choice you only have his word to go by). In several instances the choice comes down to who you believe over others, which can be fine, but i.m.o. not when a single wrong choice can lock you into the bad ending and there is no way to reload without starting a new game.

By far however my main gripe with this game is the ending: after starting the story [i]in medias res[/i] and raising a huge amount of questions regarding the setting (who are the knights who captured you? Where do they come from? Why are they so obsessed with purging evil from others through torture?....) the endgame cops out by telling you the entire experience was a dreamlike “second chance” your character had to see if he could be worthy of redemption after his suicide. Nothing needs explanation, because everything was symbolic. From this, I am disappoint.

Tormentum - Dark Sorrow est un point & click qui s'articule de la manière suivante : on ramasse des objets permettant d’activer des puzzles relativement simples lesquels une fois résolus fournissent de nouveaux objets ou libèrent l’accès à une nouvelle zone (entre 4 et 10 écrans).
	 
[h1]Points forts[/h1]
[list]
[*] Univers dark fantasy brillant rappelant la patte de Hans Ruedi Giger !
[*] Une musique qui renforce l'ambiance et des sons peu nombreux mais qui sonnent juste.
[*] Des choix éthiques à faire (tuer ou non, libérer ou non…) incitent à rejouer car ils influencent la fin du jeu et sont tous liés à des succès.
[/list]
	 
	 
[h1]Points faibles[/h1]
[list]
[*] Scénario léger et dialogues passables (ce sont plutôt des monologues). Par ailleurs, le discours philosophique est basique et sonne creux.
[*] Durée de vie ridiculement courte avec un premier walkthrough en 2h30 !
[*] Quelques éléments rappelant le manque de moyens des développeurs. Par exemple l'utilisation d'un fondu au noir pour dissimuler certaines actions qui auraient nécessité un gros travail d'animation. On notera aussi l'absence d'animations pour le personnage principal que l'on ne peut déplacer et qui se retrouve statique dans chacun des écrans (je n'ai pour ma part pas trouvé gênant ce choix de design).
[/list]
 
[h1]Ma note : 7/10[/h1] (6/10 pour les férus de challenge)
 
Très accessible, Tormentum - Dark Sorrow peut-être un bon choix pour les aventuriers peu exigeants en terme de challenge. La balade est belle et chaque écran est un régal pour les yeux ce qui peut facilement faire oublier ses carences narratives. Bref un jeu sauvé par son ambiance et son univers. A se procurer, toutefois, à petit prix.

This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watch if you are looking for a more in-depth review.

Tormentum-Dark Sorrow is a 2d point and click adventure with a dark and malevolent theme. The interface is clean and streamlined, and the game itself is fairly simplistic. You start off as a prisoner that goes on a journey of discovery through wastelands, purgatory, and redemption. It is evident that you have some sort of amnesia, but I found overall that the progression or motivation was hampered by too much missing story, information/lore along the way. It felt as if half the game went by when I blinked, as you are left not really knowing the deeper meanings of what was going on. Some of these questions in the end were answered, but not all. There was little if any lore or backstory, and it felt empty and slightly frustrating to want to know more about the world or my character, but was unable to. 

The unique art style and atmosphere made this game enjoyable. It was original and intriguing, but didn't overdo the sense of horror or the bizarre. The atmosphere of the world synergized very well together. 

One unique element to the game was that choices you make throughout the game will impact how it ends. Nothing huge or game changing,  but it was spread out and implemented well. Some of the choices might not have the impact you expected, which was misleading to say the least. You are presented with a truly evil man, for example, and your choice to kill him or let him live might not be judged as guilty or innocent as you think it would. 

The gameplay is heavy on puzzles, with some scavenging quests thrown in. I would say about 75% of the items needed for scavenging come from previous quests. I find this refreshing, as it relies more on puzzles and mini-games, instead of "find the safety deposit box in a room of 500 safety deposit boxes". The puzzles were smooth and continuous, with a good sense of fluidity that kept me enthralled in the gameplay. 

The artistic beauty, fluid game play, and overall synergy of the game make this an easy recommend. The story leaves a bit to be desired, but overall an enjoyable game.

I'll start off by saying I really don't want to give this a thumbs down, but unfortunately Steam doesn't have a "On the fence" button. So instead I'll just cut to the chase.

VISUALS:
-If you enjoy dark fantasy and surreal art- the gothic, the baroque, the grotesque- GET THIS GAME.
- If you like art in games, hope to make art for games, or just like creativity in games and want inspiration- GET THIS.
- If you're a fan of Giger or Beksinski, DEFINITELY GET THIS GAME. 

I don't really have to go into detail on this. The screenshots speak for themselves. 

LENGTH: 
The game is very short. This is a 3 to 4 hour game, sans any mucking about in confusion. Not really a detriment in its own right, but definitely a factor to consider.

GAMEPLAY/PUZZLES:
 The game isn't challenging. I can't remember the last time I played a point and click game, but I still breezed through this. This could be seen as a blessing for casual players just looking to experience the art firsthand, but I'm certain it would be underwhelming for any seasoned point-and-click fan. 

WRITING:
 It's lackluster. It's not awful, but considering what the game was trying to do it needed to do much better here. I'll avoid spoilers but it’s important to know that the writing in the game is inseparable from moral choice. The story, the theme and the visuals of the game ultimately revolve around death, sins, punishment and things not being what they seem. This could have been incredible, but for a game so trenched in morality, it is portrayed as very black and white. 

There are two endings to this game and around 7 moral choices you must make. They're fairly rudimentary , and even doing two perceived 'bad' choices will give you the bad ending. Morality is very complicated and needs to be handled as such if your whole story hinges on exploring these themes. Games like Silent Hill 2, Spec Ops: The Line and The Walking Dead all accomplished this with flying colors, and had that quality of writing gone into a game like this the end result would have been haunting. Of this I have no doubt.

As it stands however, the end result is this world of beautiful visuals and unsettling atmosphere that winds up being in the service of a lot of nothing. If you're looking for a great story, interesting characters or strong worldbuilding (particularly revolving around morality and the darkness in the human heart), you will be disappointed.  

OVERALL: 
I bought the game on impulse and my choice to buy it was exclusively rooted in the artwork. I didn't go in with any other expectations so personally, I'm happy with what I got out of it and do no regret anything. But I cannot say with confidence that this would be the case with somebody else so I leave it at this: 

If you came here for the art- go for it. An art book or ticket to a gallery show or museum often cost way more than 12$, and here the art is interactive. That's just awesome. You can't do much better than that.

 Just don't expect much else from it.

Tormentum – Dark Sorrow: das Kleinod für Adventure-Fans

Tormentum – Dark Sorrow habe ich eher durch Zufall bei Steam entdeckt. Die Bezeichnung des Genres „Point&Klick“ ist nur halbwegs zutreffend. In erster Linie ist das Spiel ein „Puzzler“ der eine gelungene Symbiose aus Adventure und Point&Klick bildet.

Story: Ich kann leider dazu nicht viel sagen, ohne euch das Spiel zu verderben. Allerdings kann ich die Rahmenhandlung in wenigen Worten schildern: Amnesie trifft Verderben, trifft Entscheidungen, trifft düstere Fantasywelt, trifft Skrupel, trifft Entscheidungen (ach das hatten wir schon)

Grafik: Die Grafiken und Hintergründe sind handgezeichnet und suchen ihresgleichen in der Adventurewelt. Ich habe selten so ein tolles und liebevolles Artdesing gesehen wie in diesem Spiel. Es erinnert ein wenig an die „Souls-Reihe“. Abgerundet wird das große Ganze mit einem abgedrehten NPC-Desing, was aus der Feder von Guillermo del Toro hätte stammen können. 

Gameplay: Ich war überrascht, das es mehrere Möglichkeiten gibt das Spiel zu beenden. Überlegt euch eure Entscheidungen sehr (sehr!) gut. Die Rätsel sind auch von Einsteigern zu schaffen, wenn man sich die Zeit nimmt genau hinzuschauen und zu erkunden… Man wird in jedem Fall belohnt. Aber es gibt auch echte Kopfnüsse, die schon einiges an Hirnschmalz abverlangen. Um so erfreulicher ist das „JA!!! geschafft!-Gefühl“. Bis man dann in den nächsten Raum vordringen darf, wo schon wieder das nächste Rätsel wartet. Fantastisch…. Aber Tormentum hat auch seine ruhigen Phasen, wo der Spieler „verschnaufen“ kann. Zu erwähnen wäre evtl. auch, dass das Spiel keine Hotspotanzeige hat, was in der heutigen Zeit nicht selbstverständlich ist. Lasst die Maus den Bildschirm erkunden! Ausnahmen bilden hier die „Schlüsselobjekte“, welche durch ein sanftes Leuchten auf sich aufmerksam machen.

Musik: Der Soundtrack fügt sich nahtlos in das Spiel ein und trägt immens zur Atmosphäre bei. Von melancholisch bis fröhlich ist alles dabei. PS: Ich liebe das „Geklimper vom Eierschneider“ in der Mine“ ;o)

Ich habe das Spiel in knapp 6 Stunden beendet… und ich wollte mehr. Mehr Rätsel, mehr von allem. Da das Spiel 2 Enden hat, ist der Wiederspielwert = + 100%. 

Gezockt habe ich das Spiel in kompletter deutschen Untertiteln (es gibt keine Sprachausgabe. Ich bin froh darüber, das es vermutlich die Immerision zerstört hätte).

Für Datensammler: Das Savegame befindet sich in „Steam\steamapps\common\Tormentum“. Die Datei lautet „dat.xlg“.

Had this game for the longest time, but put off playing it because of the dark themes.
True, the implied and graphical torment in this game was disturbing, but the story and concept were great and intriguing.

Story:
Not sure what to say without spoiling the story, but it's not standard fare "random hero saves random world from random threat". Consider it a story about one man's road to redemption. Whether or not he succeeds is entirely up to the player.
I really like how choices really do matter in this game. What you decide now changes who appears later in the story, and definitely affects the end as well.
Game length short - about 2-3 hours from start to finish, but definitely has replayability value.

Artwork:
Not sure how to classify the graphics in my opinion, but I'd say that they're unique, gorgeous, grotesque, well-detailed, imaginative and basically amazing all rolled into one.
I like how they separated the foreground and background in a lot of scenes and has a "slide" effect when you move your mouse towards the left or right.

Music:
Most of the game's background music is made up of atmospheric tracks and sound effects.
The ending song is really good. Got distracted while listening the song for both endings, so I can't say for sure if they are different songs.

Puzzles:
Every single puzzle is solvable without needing to refer anywhere out of the game.
Unlike most Daedalic point and click games, there is no guesswork needed as clues are provided appropriately where there's no way you can figure out a puzzle with simply logic (although clues are still provided for logic puzzles as well since there is no skip button). Never had to look for a walkthrough at any time at all.

Random non-gamebreaking bugs:
-> the "x" move sign/option disappearing if you go through the zoomed-in scenes too quickly. Easily fixed by exiting to the main menu or game and then continuing the game.
-> the matching mini-game becomes unresponsive if you happened to match the last pair at the same time the timer resets. Easily fixed by exiting the mini-game, although you'll end up having to restart the mini-game.

Overall a fantastic, well-made game. I feel it's worth every penny the developers ask for it.

Tormentum - Dark Sorrow ist ein Point&Click Adventure, mit einer Reihe abwechslungsreicher Puzzle Rätseleinlagen.

Auf der anderen Seite kann man bei einem Preis von ca. 10 Euro auch nicht viel falsch machen und erhält dafür ein einzigartiges Spielerlebnis und gute Rätselunterhaltung. Eine klare Kaufempfehlung daher von mir.

Oh well. Guess my soul is doomed, because there's no way I'm replaying this.

While the morality system tied to the ending has a few issues, Tormentum is an intriguing, if relatively basic hidden object and puzzle-centric adventure game. The main draw is the Giger and Beksinski-inspired dark art and the atmosphere of the decaying, corrupted world, but there's a competent enough game underneath it, if a relatively simple one. For what it is, it's a fairly interesting, non-stressful experience; there are a few points at which your progress might be delayed by a puzzle or a hidden item, but otherwise, it's a fairly straightforward affair.

Don't expect this to compare in any capacity to the juggernauts of the genre, and don't expect a large, expansive title. You'll get 2-3 hours out of an initial run, maybe more if you do any extra runs to get both endings and all the choices. If you've ever wanted to play a decent hidden object game and one with a darker atmosphere, this will work for you. However, if you want a proper adventure game with some actually meat to it, I'd recommend that you look elsewhere; this is more a twisted, Eldritch piece of candy that excites the tastebuds, but ultimately leaves you with empty calories.

This game is dark, despondent, despairing and depending on how one defines horror, it could be that too.  A point and click not so adventurous "adventure" game.  (Adventure because it does fall into any other catergory, not really, other then maybe supernatural.  But even that would be a stretch.)  Has a moralistic tone of more right vs wrong, then good vs evil.  

Story: The condemned arrives with a fellow prisoner at a castle specifically designed for torture, torment, and purging souls of their evil through pain, suffering, and grief.  (Dark, very dark, in tone.)  The condemned man is told this in his jail cell by the horned guard, who also informs the condemned man he (the guard) will back to torture him.  Of course, the condemned man does not wait around for that.  This begins the journey through the Hell-bound castle, and meeting its various denizans.  After that it is a trip though the wastelands, dealing with the inhabitants, and eventually to the condemned man's goal, a structure of uprised arms with a shrouded female statue inside.  Ethical choices are made throughout, in the simply question kill or not kill.   

I could get into a huge philosophical discussion right about now (especially after reading other reviews, in particular the negative ones) but I will spare everyone this.  But the game and that simple life-death question does have a thought poking quality that can not be denied.  (Oh by the way I considered every entity in this game to be "evil", some just less "evil" then others, even before I finished reading the Immanuel Kant introduction.)

The game is short (I suppose).  Some say they finished in about 2 hours.  I took much longer enjoying the amazing, stunning, awe-inspiring artwork.  I am not one to talk much artwork or graphics but words like astonishing, stupefying, shocking and startling could all be used to describe this game's artwork.  This game brings to mind the paintings of Hell and Judgement done by Hieronymus Bosch (Netherland).  Now add to that the H.R. Giger (Switzerland) influence (best known for the creature 'Alien') and the Zdzislaw Beksinski (Polish) influence the developers and designers used as inspiration and Dante's Inferno (many reviewers refer to) seems like Heaven.  The art work alone is worth the game price.  (Art museum admissions cost more for this much art viewing, and one can keep this.)

Gameplay: This is a point and click game with puzzles, and plays in a linear fashion with goals that need to be accomplished.  It is played in 3D so the scene moves back and forth, and along the edges arrows appear if the gamer can go in that direction.  There are basically 4 segments to this game, castle, wastelands, town, conclusion.  The castle, wastelands, and town can also be broken in 2 subsections each.   

Puzzles: Many think the puzzles are too easy.  I think hard puzzles would simply distract from the overall ambience of the entire game.  For me, this is a story about the journey, the encounters that occur on that journey, and the decisions made on that journey, not the puzzles.  Though I must say for me the highlight puzzle was a 'slider/make the gears spin' puzzle.  I could almost hear groans and sighs from those who simply detest both types of those puzzles because they were in the same puzzle. Puzzle types include logic, sliders, and codes in various forms.

Overall I think the game is worth the price and the play.  It is a journey game, not an adventure game, however, so that should be kept in mind in the gamer's decision making.

AUDIO

18198440.review:
Главное очарование Tormentum: Dark Sorrow держится на визуальном стиле и тяжёлой dark-ambient музыке. Проектов, столь обильно наполненных такой мрачной атмосферой, можно по пальцам пересчитать, так давайте рассмотрим, почему это отличная игра, несмотря на то, что имеет несколько проблем.

Жанр игры – приключенческий квест. Игровой процесс представляет собой поиск предметов, простые разговоры с немногочисленными собеседниками и решение банальных задачек. Изучать локации только ради игры вряд ли будет интересно: задачи тут столь просты, что добрую половину можно решить с наскока. А десяток подсказок и вовсе убивает желание внимательно изучать задачу на предмет выгодного решения. Однако головоломки разнообразные, и хоть сколько-то похожих друг на друга вы не сыщете. Так что, если вы не большой любитель по пять часов ломать мозг над одной головоломкой, вы наверняка останетесь в добром расположении духа от прохождения. Зато у игры есть козырь – это возможность делать выборы. Большинство из них сводится к тому, чтобы грохнуть кого-нибудь или пощадить, но есть и интересные моменты, которые могут изменить даже парочку из следующих локаций.

Вот только с сюжетом тут не сложилось. Он повествует о существе, которое должно найти кое-какие ответы на важные для него вопросы. И, так как вопросы эти были поставлены в самом начале, логично было бы предположить, что ответы на них должны были перевернуть наше, игроков, представление с ног на голову. К сожалению, ничего подобного. И дело тут даже не в примитивных и безынтересных диалогах, а в том, что сам финал явно подкачал. Во-первых, главное объяснение вместе с исходом решений вышло крайне скомканным. Во-вторых, финал не учитывает конкретные решения игрока, а только их количество. Если хоть одно из ваших решений будет по характеру отличным от других, ожидайте иную концовку, слабо состыковавшуюся с вашими действиями. Печально, что решения в итоге привели к банальному добру и злу. Кажется, будто сценарий первых двух третей игры писал один сценарист, а концовку подгонял другой.

Справедливости ради стоит уточнить, что до того, как игрок достигнет финала, последствия некоторых решений могут задать вопросы моральным принципам игрока, и это замечательно. Но слабая концовка всё-таки ставит под сомнение смысловую нагрузку всех решений.

Нельзя простить отвратительную оптимизацию. Вся графика представляет собой заранее нарисованные отдельные куски картинки, которые вполне мог бы воспроизвести компьютер пятнадцатилетней давности, но игра, заблокированная на тридцати кадрах, умудряется на видеокартах 2013-го года притормаживать до пятнадцати в совершенно случайных местах без какой-либо причины. Игра, конечно, не падает, но по атмосфере эти тормоза ударяют больно.

Но! Можете перечеркнуть и выбросить за борт лёгкий игровой процесс и заваленный финал. Ведь игра полностью захватит ваше внимание визуалом и музыкой. Все локации в игре основаны на работах таких замечательных художников, как Здислав Бексинский и, внимание, Ганс Рудольф Гигер. Да, тот самый, кто придумал образ Чужого. Согласитесь, что работы этих двух уже дают гарантию того, что игра получится ну очень аутентичной. Каждая локация пронизана тяжёлой и густой атмосферой самых мрачных мыслей, что только может выдумать человек. Большая часть времени игры вообще уходит на разглядывание каждой мелочи на локации, ибо художники игры постарались наполнить каждый уголок чем-нибудь интересным, раскрывающим историю мира. Посмотрите кадры из игры и убедитесь в том, что вся игра состоит из этих произведений изобразительного искусства. Колоссaльная работа!

Не отстаёт от художников и композитор. В начале и середине музыка буквально пробирает до мурашек своей грандиозной монструозностью, тяжестью настоящего dark-ambient’а. Правда, тема на титрах хоть и очень хороша, но совершенно не соответствует общему настрою музыки в остальной части игры, но хуже она не сделает. В любом случае, некоторые, особенно чувственные композиции, не грех добавить в личный плей-лист.

Итак, игра рекомендуется тем, кто остался в восторге от её визуального стиля; тем, кто хочет проникнуться мрачной, густой атмосферой; тем, кто желает послушать классную ambient-музыку; а также людям, кто не против сыграть в не очень продолжительный квест и не желает слишком долго ломать голову над решениями зубодробительных задачек. Такие дела.
