17593735.review:
[h1]Tormentum: Dark Sorrow[/h1]
[b]Developer[/b]: OhNoo Studio
[b]Publisher[/b]: OhNoo Studio

[b]Note[/b]: A key for this game was provided by the developer for the purpose of writing an unbiased, informative review. No other compensation was given.

[b]Introduction[/b]
==========
Inspired by HR Giger's unique biomechanical style and games such as Dark Souls and Dark Seed, Tormentum: Dark Sorrow is an extremely dark point and click adventure, diving deep into themes such as damnation, sin, and redemption. While somewhat short, Tormentum is a nearly unforgettable adventure spanning across 3 different realms. Fans of this genre may find something here that rivals other titles' quality! Let's take a closer look at what Tormentum has to offer.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
==========
As a point and click adventure, the game plays out entirely at your pace. Progression is limited by your ability to find hidden secrets and solve puzzles. This is done by clicking objects and areas on-screen to uncover them. Hidden objects are able to be picked up, stored on your bag, and used in other areas, typically assisting in solving puzzles presented to the player. 

As you solve puzzles, you slowly gain access to more areas of the dark castle your character is being held prisoner in. Each area is it's own puzzle, so to speak, and by carefully examining each area will you piece together each puzzle. Some rooms have NPCs, which will help or hinder you, depending on certain factors. Usually they will give you an item needed to progress, in exchange for solving another, smaller puzzle or task. One NPC is a guard who gives you a shovel to dug up a piece of gold, and rewards you with a necklace that is actually a key to a door nearby--just as an example. There are many areas to explore, and many puzzles to solve!

An important aspect of the game is the Journal. It automatically keep notes on important bits of imformation you find, such as a diagram of a point of interest you find somewhere, or a crude drawing providing a clue left behind by another prisoner of the castle. This can be checked at anytime, as well as your bag where your items are kept.

Lastly, at certain points of the game you are presented with some moral choices, literally good or evil. Depending on your choices, you may get the good or bad ending...which is basically how your character is judged at the very end of the story. If you are aiming for a particular ending, make sure you hit all the right choices, a single mistake can change your ending entirely.

[b]Graphics[/b]
==========
As mentioned before, Tormentum's unique art style is heavily inspired by games such as Dark Souls and Dark Deeds, and by famous painter and sculptor HR Giger.  Giger is credited with designing the monster simply known as the 'Alien' or Xenomorph from the classic 1979 film of the same name. Giger has a very unique style, blending biological and mechanical components together to create a unique blend of flesh and machine. This is prominently seen and featured in nearly every scene of Tormentum, and in most NPC designs. This style works very well for the setting.

Hand-painted stages help to blend everything together, and are a wonder to behold. Half the fun of the game is pushing onwards just to see the next area and it's art. Everything is incredibly dark and very detailed.

[b]Sound and Music[/b]
==========
Featuring over 40 spine-tingling tracks, Tormentum has quite the soundtrack to help immerse you into the story and setting. Slow, yet hopeful tunes for the more docile scenes, with darker more evil tracks for the hellish scenes you will encounter. Nothing is amiss here, and it all comes together to create a memorable experience.

[b]Performance[/b]
==========
For this type of game, a high framerate isn't needed, which is good because Tormentum ran at an acceptable 30FPS at all times. I did not run into any bugs, random crashes, or stuttering at any point. There are very few video/audio options, but honestly they are hardly needed.

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
==========
Tormentum: Dark Sorrow is an excellent point and click adventure, one you are bound to remember long after you finish it. Although short, it's filled with clever puzzles and hidden secrets. It's dark style, artwork, and soundtrack are the best features. Fans of the genre will find a very enjoyable experience with Tormentum, and anyone who isn't a fan may just be converted into one!

[b]Gameplay Demo[/b]
==========
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gjqSD2YhPOA

[b]Nerd House Verdict[/b]:
==========
[h1][b]Highly Recommended[/b][/h1]

17146160.review:
The fact that I'd never heard of this game before yesterday is proof that I'm following the wrong kinds of game news outlets. It's lavishly detailed, dripping with atmosphere, and full of the sort of weird, imaginative, borderline nightmarish imagery that I'm always on the lookout for. Mature point-and-click adventures are coming back, and I couldn't be happier.

P&Cs have a (deserved) reputation as being full of obtuse puzzles that are more about reading the designer's mind than using a realistic problem solving approach. I'm happy to report that isn't the case here. Each puzzle (and there are quite a lot of them) has a well-conveyed goal and comes together logically. For every minigame you've seen before -- slide the blocks, connect the wires, or match the tiles -- there's another that's new and interesting, and even the familiar ones often come with a twist.

For me, games are first and formost about offering the player a new world to explore, and Tormentum delivers beautifully on that end. I'll admit I groaned when my character played the amnesia card at the very beginning, but it works out surprisingly well -- this world is as alien to him as it was to me. It's a bizarre setting full of creatures and locales both otherworldly and twistedly familiar, yet everything is presented in such an unassuming, matter-of-fact way that it never stops feeling believable. It's a world you're dropped into without any explanation - because you don't need one. No lore-heavy monologues or lists of invented names to be found here. It's about as earnest and unpretentious a fantasy setting as I've ever seen.

I like the inclusion of moral choices, though they can be a little too obvious -- I don't personally subscribe to the belief that there is no right and wrong, only "shades of grey", but I do appreciate it when I'm forced to make a decision without having all the answers. With a few exceptions, the choices you'll be making are pretty clear-cut between right and wrong, and given the surreal setting, I would have hoped for a bit more ambiguity. Still, they add a nice layer of reactivity to the story and offer welcome motivation to play through more than once.

The one real complaint I have is about the controls. Moving the mouse simultaneously pans the scene in parallax while also moving the cursor, meaning that objects on screen move as you move the cursor towards them. You have to actively guide the cursor instead of allowing your muscle memory to do the heavy lifting. It also (for me) caused some amount of light motion sickness early on. Your milage may vary of course.

Ultimately I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this game. It's a refreshing surprise that ticks all the boxes I care about. Check out the demo if you're still on the fence, but personally, this is one impulse buy I don't regret in the slightest.

16405049.review:
[b]Tormentum: Dark Sorrow[/b] (Casual Adventure)

Very simple options with this one: Sliders for music and sound effects, and full-screen or not. In addition, there are nine languages to choose from.

If you play the demo, you'll find that the game seems to be more of a puzzle game than an adventure, with just a few screens and puzzles before moving on to the next area. This does NOT hold true for the rest of the game. You'll be locked out of some areas once you leave them, but there are plenty of locations to move about, puzzles to solve, and story to discover as you progress.

There are no hints, no skips, and no map. I did not have any trouble completing the game, nonetheless. Nothing I came across was frustratingly hard, and the only real problem I had was missing obvious things on the screen, like something I needed to interact with or an exit I simply didn't see. :p

Every screen scrolls left and right a bit, depending on where your cursor is. Although it would have been nice to just see the full scenes, some of the puzzles involve this scrolling mechanism, so I can't complain.

Speaking of the puzzles, be VERY CAREFUL when you are solving them, and really pay attention to what you're doing! Sometimes there is more than one way to solve a puzzle, and your actions really matter in this game. Your decisions count, so choose wisely.

The art style is dark and disturbing, but also beautifully done and very evocative. Combine this with the well-chosen music tracks, and you have a deeply environmental experience that will question your morals and life choices.

For the achievement hunters like myself, there are 34 achievements to obtain, which will require you to play through the game at least twice. I'm pretty sure most people won't mind going through a second time, as there are two endings!

There is a lot of bonus content to look at, which is not necessary to complete the game, but will enhance the experience. Some of these things will earn your achievements (such as reading all of the books,) so be aware of that.

While [i]Tormentum: Dark Sorrow[/i] is on the short side (around four hours for my first play-through,) the multiple endings and fascinating world which the devs have created make it absolutely worth owning. Definitely recommended, and I'm looking forward to OhNoo Studio's next game~! :D

[h1][b]Review: Tormentum - Dark Sorrow[/b][/h1]

[i][b]“Act in such a way that you treat humanity, whether in your own person or in the person of any other, never merely as a means to an end, but always at the same time as an end.” 

Immanuel Kant[/b][/i]

This is what Tormentum starts with, a well known quotation from one of the most popular philosophers Germany has to offer. What defines human ethics? Is reason the source of morality? You should know by now that Tormentum neither answers this questions solely nor tries to do so, but stimulating the player’s mind with radical issues presented in gruesome but hand-painted actions and pictures instead of reading Kant’s essay might work better, at least for gamers. Your actions and decisions will affect your story, always leaving you behind with one question left. Did I make the [b][i]right[/i][/b] choice? 

Introduction done. Don’t worry, this is not about philosophy, it is about [b]Tormentum[/b], a game that looks like our worst nightmares got caught and painted by H.R.Giger. Some of those bad dreams might even haunt you after the game is over but even then you just can’t stop looking at every small detail, whether it looks amusing, terrifying or violent. Speaking of terror and violence, we should take a look at Tormentum’s story. You are...well. Who are you? You are somebody,  yet no one. A poor creature wearing a capuchin, that gets imprisoned in an old, horrendous looking castle, threatened with torture and punishment for sins you cannot remember. Survival is your only thought and thus keeps your motivation alive even after having seen the suffering your new home has to offer. Prepare for morale choices that will not only affect yourself and keep that one thing in mind: Nobody is what they claims to be. 

While Tormentum does look like a classic point-and-click at first sight, it uses some hidden object influences, mixes it up and combines them with classical puzzles and riddles. These are not unbeatable since you will find many clues but expect to be fairly challenged. May it be the right time on a watch, a certain melody that needs to be played or a man-eating worm that blocks your path, you will love the variety. There is no button for highlighting things, some objects have a unique glow instead whilst others can be hard to find sometimes. Additionally, objects can neither be combined in your inventory nor used for multiple actions. This may sounds simple but it fits the idea Tormentum wants to convey. The only time this really bothered me was early on after the start where you get confronted with many different scenes and tasks. If one link is missing in the chain you get stuck forever, running through the same backgrounds multiple times. These are eyecatchers even after passing them again and again, so do not lose  your confidence, there is a clue or hint for everything. 

Before listing major points, I want to take a second look at the atmosphere Tormentum creates. I can’t talk enough about the graphics, or better, art OhNoo Studio created here. There won’t be many scenes you may find peaceful or cheering though, but would you really expect that to happen when a game is called Tormentum? You will witness pain, torture and suffering, everywhere. One can only imagine how a world would look like where evil lurks everywhere and redemption seems to be the only escape, but if this world really exists I fear it would look like Tormentum. Creepy People and Creatures, a dying land, epic but disgusting monuments, fire that rains from the sky, everything brought to life or death with hand-drawn masterpieces. Whoever created the soundtrack and effects should be awarded, too. My first impression was a bit monotonous but it quickly became the perfect skin for its cadaverous body. Emotions can be heard without even knowing what happens in the current scene. 

[h1]Big Text, Quick Facts:[/h1]

[b]Pro:[/b]
[list]
[*]Oustanding artwork, inspired by H.R.Giger and Others - brutal and otherworldly
[*]Emotional Plot with moral choices and multiple endings - mature and philosophical
[*]A soundtrack that captures the essence of pain and sorrow
[*]Various Puzzles and Riddles offer good challenges - without interrupting the plot too much
[*]Interesting side stories to learn - Nobody is what he claims to be
[/list]

[b]Con:[/b]
[list]
[*]Every riddle has a hint - but finding those gets annoying sometimes since objects cannot be highlighted and some puzzles simply can’t be solved without the matching clue
[*]Some things will happen - no matter which choice you made
[*]Small bug - using steam overlay lowers the fps while writing. Chatting and Tormentum shouldn’t be combined anyway. 
[/list]

[h1][b][u]Summary:[/u][/b][/h1]

Seeing this game getting Greenlit made me proud and happy since I backed it on Kickstarter myself, but when it got released the two of us couldn’t match. I am not a fan of Hidden Object games and playing the first couple of minutes I felt that this was not the game I expected. My opinion changed as you might have already guessed. 

Once the story gets its hands on you, luring you with choices, challenging with puzzles, playing with morality and disturbing with violence, Tormentum starts to become more than just a piece of unforgettable sound, visuals and artwork. Staring at the screen for more than 5 minutes, pondering your next decision, you will ask yourself again: What is the right choice? Whether you know Kant or not, this will affect you. 

Verdict: 8,5 / 10

15801102.review:
By raising $11,000 on Indiegogo, Tormentum: Dark Sorrow proves that point and click adventure games still have an audience. And at first glance, it's easy to see why: not only did OhNoo Studio create a hellishly beautiful game, they lowered the puzzle difficulty so as to appeal to a larger audience.

Speaking of puzzles, let's talk about game design. In Tormentum, players do not control their avatar directly; instead, they click left, right, up or down in order to progress through a series of moderately interactive screens. As to the puzzles themselves, they appear in two forms. The first requires players search for a particular object, such as a bone to appease a hungry animal or a key to unlock a prison cell. Secondly, Tormentum is filled with mini-games. These mini games often possess puzzle elements—for example, adjusting a set of gears to open a door—but not always.

Experienced point and click adventure fans may have noticed that I didn't mention item combinations. That's because there aren't any. OhNoo Studio ditches item combinations in order to lower their game's difficulty while providing a minimalistic inventory system. Does this decision pay off? In the end, I have to say no. The puzzle design in Tormentum never strays too far from easy, and genre veterans will breeze through this game.

That said, easy puzzles shouldn't distract from the game's biggest triumph: tone. All of the art in Tormentum is hand-drawn and disturbingly ghoulish, with many monsters seemingly torn from the pages of a H.P. Lovecraft novel. The world alternates between horrible, bleak, and ravaged. No one finds goodness in Tormentum, a sentiment echoed by the game's ominous and occasionally plaintive soundtrack.

With decent gameplay and strong art, I'd consider recommending Tormentum were it not for the game's terrible story. OhNoo Studio bundles two video game clichés with a vague plot and obvious morality system. Amnesiac protagonist? Check. Absolving murderers good and killing innocents bad? Check. The nail in the coffin is the game's English translation: though Tormentum is more or less devoid of blatant errors, several awkward phrases took me out of the story.

When I think of Tormentum, I think of missed opportunity. What if this game had put a price on being good, encouraging the player to make the evil choice instead? What if the developers had fleshed out the plot? While Tormentum: Dark Sorrow could have left me contemplating life, OhNoo Studio settled for style over substance. This point and click adventure will have its fans, but don't count me among them.

FINAL SCORE: 5.8/10

Yes...and no? But yes.

Tormentum is something of a newer variety of point and click games. Ones that focus a lot more on the logic puzzles rather than the classic Monkey Island style of "try this with this, and maybe this, and maybe if you're lucky it'll work because why not". They're very straightforward as point and click games go and with a few exception, very finely crafted.

But with that, they're also very easy. In fact, your typical point and click gamer, especially of the older variety, might find themselves a bit miffed at just how straightforward these puzzles are. Almost to the point I couldn't help but think to myself, "how on earth am I doing all this so easily and yet so many others in this setting have utterly FAILED?" And that can be a bit of a damper simply because for the most part, just about anyone can cruise through the game with nary a problem. There's just about no challenge.

I'm not quite sure I can bring myself to call that a flaw though. The amospheric aura of the game combined with its crisp--though admittedly not nearly as talented as its visual art--writing and very lean, clean cut gameplay really just allows you as the player to truly focus on the game for what it is. And that is an evocative art gallery of introspection. Just like any other wonderful piece of art. This is one of the few games I've ever played that leveraged a morality system...and still made me question my choices. Where the results of your choices oftentimes came back to haunt you later, leaving you thinking to yourself "...oh shit...did I...did I fuck up? Was that REALLY the right decision?". And it's absolutely beautiful.

Another thing to note about the game that could be construed as a flaw is its length. It's pretty short. Anywhere between 2 to 5 hours. It does have some replay value but the game is still short despite that. But in all honesty, I find that length for better rather than worse. Any longer and the game might be overstaying its welcome. You really don't want to become desensitized to an artstyle like Tormentum's.

And one more thing. I'll admit that I was a tad bit disappointed to see that the game didn't have as much...uh, grotesque, visual torture as I had thought based on the demo. That's...probably a good thing. And in all honesty, led to a far more cohesive game probaby. But I'll just throw out there for those who were looking.

All in all, I highly recommend Tormentum for anyone who is willing to go through a dark, surreal, and visceral visual journey of the mind and eye. With that being said, I do not recommend this game to anyone who's a bit on the squeamish side and probably not for minors. The art can be very grotesque at times in a pretty disturbing way. I also caution veterans of the point and click genre to approach knowing that the game is pretty darn easy. And finally, I don't suggest this game to anyone who's searching for something with a more adrenaline tick. The game is eerie, but it is by no means "horror". And anyone who would not enjoy point and click mechanics simply has little to find here outside of the aesthetics.

But really. Play this game. It's well worth the money. And then some.

15334411.review:
Разработчики из OhNoo! Studio выбрали идеальный способ поглубже забраться к вам под кожу: Tormentum - Dark Sorrow выглядит, звучит и ощущается как оживший коллективный кошмар Гигера, Дали и Лавкрафта. Или, если угодно, как совместный плод их воображения, если предположить на секунду, что мастера по необъяснимой потусторонней причине внезапно оказались в одно время и в одном месте. Три по-хорошему больных разума укоренились в одном теле и организовали инсталляцию.

Не исключено, что к компании мог прибиться ещё один знатный визионер, извращенец и живой культ миллионов - Клайв Баркер.

Во время игры не оставляет впечатление, что на самом деле листаешь альбом "Некрономикон" и одновременно падаешь в бездонную пропасть, а не сидишь на заднице и пялишься в монитор. Сложно объяснить, как такое происходит и почему - нужно просто попробовать и постараться переварить. При этом авторы не перегибают знаменитую палку "Всё плохо, мы все умрём" и вносят в аудиовизуальную мрачноту проблеск в виде убийственной иронии, чёрного юмора и зыбкой надежды на лучшее. Tormentum ежеминутно давит, угнетает, развлекает, но дарит шанс на спасение из мира бесконечного ночного кошмара.

Персонажи и история подобрались подстать общему настрою: безумцы едут на безумцах и безумцами погоняют. Жестокий орден рыцарей, чья цитадель базируется в краю бесконечных метеоритных дождей, странствует по свету на уродливых дирижаблях, похищает разумных существ и затем пытает их в своих сырых казематах. Иногда и вовсе вырезает целые города. А всё ради того, чтобы изгнать таким образом из грешников зло и скверну. Высшая миссия, не иначе. Главный герой - беспамятный и безымянный, классика! - по счастливой случайности сбегает из темницы и начинает своё странствие по миру, где все врут и втайне мечтают убить друг друга наиболее жестоким способом.

На протяжении всего пути нам предстоит исследовать пугающие локации, решать разнообразные загадки и общаться с местными жителями. В общем, отрабатывать стандартную программу приключенческой игры. Но сумятицу в прохождение вносят диалоги и моральные дилеммы. Стоит встретить кого-нибудь с хорошо подвешенным языком и на вас мигом вывалят свои проблемы, о чём-нибудь попросят или вынудят посодействовать. И тут в дело вступает обещанная вариативность: например, можно помиловать или казнить палача, сделать выбор между товарищем по несчастью или малознакомым типом. Последствия некоторых поступков очевидны, другие лишь косвенно влияют на финал. И до самого конца остаётся гадать, правильный ли сделан выбор и к чему это в итоге приведёт. Да и сами ситуации весьма неоднозначные.

Сильно портит удовольствие от прохождения простота головоломок - порой кажется, что тебя считают законченным болваном. Понятно, что в OhNoo! Studio не хотели отпугнуть ни новичков, ни ветеранов, но Tormentum - Dark Sorrow получилась слишком ровной и последовательной. В принципе не может возникнуть ситуации, когда не знаешь и не понимаешь, куда приладить найденный предмет. А даже если подобное случится, то всегда помогут и подскажут неотключаемая подсветка активных точек экрана и дневник, в который зачастую попадают подробные рецепты решения задачек. Но если вдруг в течение ближайших пяти минут озарение не снизошло, то расслабьтесь и проходите в следующую локацию, ответ будет прямо перед носом.

Неудивительно, что в определённый момент игра перестаёт быть игрой и превращается в альбом прекрасных мрачных иллюстраций - прекрасных, но безжизненных. Правда, могу гарантировать, что для большинства игроков это не станет непреодолимой преградой или поводом для разочарования. Спустя три-четыре часа (за которые попросту невозможно устать и пресытиться) неизменно приходишь к выводу: под маской игры скрывается притча о значении выбора и последствиях поступков. Не больше, но и не меньше.

[i]Skip to the end for a pro/con list of features. This review is spoiler-free.[/i]

Tormentum is a point & click game set in a dark world with soundtracks and art style that make it unique in its genre. The story is fairly simple and revealed slowly bit by bit, with a great twist at the end. There are no combat mechanics or even player-controlled movement, and yet at no point have I felt these things missing. You navigate the world room by room, relying on your perception to interact with your surroundings, picking up items and using objects. Collectables have a slight shine to them, which makes it a bit easier to spot them and you won't spent much time hunting down items. The game involves a lot of puzzle solving but most of them are easy enough, with only a few that can make you stuck on them (especially if you missed the hints). The graphics in this game are pure works of art, and the eerie soundtracks complete the depressing, grim feel of the world you are traversing. Every now and then you will have to make a moral choice, and these choices will essentially decide your ultimate ending. Wish the game was a bit longer, but it's not too short as it is. It would also be great if there was voice acting instead of just plain text. Overall, Tormentum has enough replayability value for at least 2 playthroughs and a total of 5-6 hours of entertainment and is in my opinion definitely worth the price.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ A well told, easy to follow story with a great twist
+ Awesome graphic style
+ Excellent soundtracks
+ Simple but powerful moral choices
+ Striking, interesting characters
+ The atmosphere is very well set and realistic

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- A bit short
- Most puzzles very easy
- No voice acting (except intro)

[b]Final verdict: 8/10[/b]

Странный продукт.
С одной стороны - простенький поинт-клик квест. Загадки незамысловатые, предметы все подсвечиваются, последовательность действий очевидная и не вызывающая тугой задумчивости. В общем, абсолютно обычный проходной квест.
С другой - интересная, пусть и уже довольно забитая, тематика потустороннего мира. Сюжет не отличается глубиной, но для игры в 2-3 часа на полное прохождение вполне достаточный. Наш альтер-эго блуждает по локациям в поисках пути к своей цели - статуе, которую он видел во сне. Все остальные воспоминания, ессно, отшибло напрочь. Нам встречаются различные персонажи, предлагающие услугу/предмет за услугу/предмет. При этом многие решения довольно интересны и имеют "вилки", кажущиеся очевидными на первый взгляд, но имеющие скрытые подтексты и смысл. Такие развилки оказывают прямое влияния на итог наших поисков и концовку игру. Соответственно, имеется реиграбильность для открытия различных вариантов и их последствий (ну и ачивки заработать, таки да=)).
Но все эти вещи - мишура по сравнению с антуражем. Вот что в этом проекте действительно восхищает- шикарные мрачные локации, гротеск, отсылающий к работам Дюрера, Гигера, Брейгеля; превосходные персонажи, идеально выдержанные в общем антураже этого темного мира - уроды, падшие на самое дно создания, мученики. Ощущение опустошенности, рока и полной безысходности происходящего витает вокруг нас всю игру. Каждая деталь прорисована до мелочей, по локациям бродишь не столько по игровым делам, а просто разглядывая пропитанные ужасом, болью и тьмой виды. 
Художники заслуживают бурных аплодисментов, обязательно стоя.
Итого - рекомендуется всем любителям стилистики мрачных потусторонних миров и очень качественно нарисованных квестов. За игрой как таковой сюда идти явно не стоит.
-/10. Оценку ставить не буду, ибо как ее оценить хоть с небольшой долей объективности - не имею понятия.

High above in the sky, locked in a cage in your gown of shadows, held from the most steampunk aircraft ever seen in a game before, across from a beauty and the beast esk monster, is where you begin this dark point and click adventure. You play as an unnamed character in dark robes, who has been captured by the dark guardians of the tower for some treason that your soul has committed. The lore and story are slowly explained to the player, that never really gives the player too much detail, creating a minimalist effect that really made the gameplay experience enjoyable. I feel like some point and click games today flood the player with story, so playing this was a sigh of relief. 

The gameplay in Tormentum follows the basic structure of point and click adventure type games. Items are found that you can pick up and put in your backpack, that might solve some of the puzzles later on in the game. This process is repeated throughout the entire game, but is kept interesting with the great number of interesting and enjoyable puzzles. Most of the time, there are cheat sheets in other locations that provide the player with graphical representations of how to complete a puzzle in a different area. This keeps the games difficulty balanced and gameplay enjoyable. 

The artstyle is unique and breathtaking when first seen, because it doesn't follow the conventional scheme of pretty games today, because Tormentum is incredibly grotesque in its detail. Every point of detail in the game has something amazing on it. The tables with blood dripping of them, to the human remains being electrocuted in the death chambers, each scene is as amazing as the last. 

The player enters a throne room with a rather wicked looking court jester sitting by the castle throne. You approach him and he tells you to kill a certain prisoner with this special knife he provides you, whilst offering the player a hefty reward. At this point in the game, the story hadn’t been described to me that much, and so I had to make the choice that my guy told me too. These choices are dark, and usually represent a good/evil decision the player needs to make. 

The games length is around 5 hours for a single playthrough. These 5 hours weren’t just a 5 hour grind of ‘gotta go here’ and ‘gotta do this’ but instead was an intense and rewarding diegetic experience. This game has plenty of  replayability with the choice system inbedded in the game, giving each playthrough a different experience. Tormentum is less a video game you play for enjoyment and more an experience that people of dark adventure would love. I would recommend Tormentum to anybody who sounds like this would be their style of game, and when it’s selling for a price point of less than $15 AUD, it’s a steal.

The game is heavily puzzle-based, and reminds me of Coktel Vision's titles, such as The Prophecy, as well as those of Dynamix, like Rise of the Dragon, or Heart of China, and even more recent efforts by companies like Daedalic Entertainment, such as the Deponia and The Dark Eye series. Tormentum boasts striking visuals, is very reminescent of the art of Zdzisław Beksiński, and H.R. Giger, and has an atmosphere similar to that found in FROM Software's "Souls" games.

The puzzles are never too complicated as to keep you stuck for hours. Highlighting effects ensure that you will never spend too much time pixel-hunting down the items needed to progress. The story is cryptic enough to keep you guessing, until the end (no spoilers here). I heartily recommend this game to adventure game fans. The presentation (both the visuals and the music) alone is certainly worth the price.

Tormentum is a puzzler at heart adorned in an adventure cape. Thrown into a prison for reasons unbeknownst to you, you are supposed to escape your cell and find your way out of whatever location you are in. 

For all the imagination that was put on the world design, there is never really any motivation for you to do anything other than to just finish the game. You will encounter multiple characters, each with their own plea and moral standing, and depending on who you assist, the game will generate one of two different endings.

Each new location presents a puzzle or an element that you will need to solve one, and their designs are absolutely striking. So much work has been put on each set-piece and all for good reason. Simple in its approach as it is, Tormentum is a beautiful game that justifies its asking price just for its aesthetic, and at $11, coupled with some interesting puzzles, it’s a bargain.

Pros:

– Beautiful landscapes and art direction specially if you are an H.R Giger fan.

– Balanced difficulty curve that has the game starting piss-easy and ending mind-numbingly challenging.

– Great use of sound and ambient

– Multiple paths that will lead to one of two different endings.

Cons

– The story is too simplistic and almost laid out for you from the outset

– Some puzzles are obtuse and others are too simplistic.

– What ending you get, evil or good, is dependent on your decisions, themselves dependent on visual cues that are not clear at times.

You're given moral choices to make throughout the game, and while some seem rather obvious, others are not so clear.

There are two endings depending on the moral choices you make. Good, and Evil. On my first playthrough, I committed two evil choices, and the rest were good. Didn't matter, as I got the evil ending. YOU CAN'T MAKE -ANY- EVIL CHOICES IF YOU'RE GOING FOR THE GOOD ENDING. One evil choice is all it takes to get the evil ending, it seems. There isn't a balanced system for measuring the moral choices at the end, so keep in mind what ending you want to pursue before beginning a playthrough. 

A lot of the puzzles in this game remind me of those brain-tester minigames you'd find on the Nintendo DS or some online flash game, and those are the only ones that present any kind of challenge. The rest of the game is finding objects hidden in the environment, and giving them to NPCs or completing mechanism & puzzles. Nothing in this game is really difficult at all, as some of the NPCs will outright tell you how to solve the puzzle, or make it entirely obvious. So, the puzzles and minigames felt really tedious. My verdict:

14799389.review:
Good things about the game:

++ Awesome art. Really, every single scene and character in the game is painted beautifully and with so much detail. Every screen is a feast for the eyes in some way, with its own dark, twisted world. Imagine someone like Geiger doing a video game. This game is proof that we do not need to be stuck in pixellated art for adventure games.
+ Atmosphere: the feeling of oppression, mortal frailty and fatality of the world comes across well. Everything attaches itself well thematically to what is going on and almost every little thing has some dark twist about it. 
+ If you are afraid of the incredibly obtuse puzzles, you have nothing to fear in this game. Despite the twisted nature of the world, the puzzles are logical and the game isn't afraid to give you open hints as to what you need to do. 
+ Different environments: again, every screen looks and feels different. Are are unlikely to see the same wall twice and the game does everything to vary the nature of the environment. The environments are actively part of the story rather than lazily copy-pasted all over. 
+ The story had a surprising twist-ending (well, it surprised me). 

Bad things about the game:
- The puzzles will not be challanging to a veteran adventure gamer. There are one or two puzzles where you can figure things out without the game giving you a solution but that's about it. However, the game still holds interest to them for its art and atmosphere. 
- Not enough oppressing/depressing music! I recall only one instance in the game where the music actively contributed to the scene. Otherwise it is fairly muted or I don't recall it at all. 
- The story does have you start with amnesia but for one driving memory. However, the character's identity is not imporant to the plot (until the end) and the story actively works with this rather than just use it out of laziness. 
- The game has a moral choice system but it is rather transparent and predictable where it goes. It falls into the trap of "doing evil for evil's sake" and rarely really tempted to do evil. Evil needs to be something that the player would chose from something other than sadism (or amoral selfishness) and good needs to be the hard, unrewarding thing to do or even something you wouldn't think to do. 
- I don't really call it a negative but the game has no hint system or even a point-of-interest highlighter. The game is design well enough that you don't need them.

The only thing I could possibly comment on is the difficulty of the puzzles. 14778545.review:
Dobra produkcja, nie bardzo dobra, ale znacznie wybijająca się ponad poziom przeciętności.

Najważniejszym plusem jest oczywiście oprawa wizualna. Przynajmniej pod względem warstwy wizualnej i kreacji świata. Mimo iż sceneria w której dzieje się akcja gry jest zmienna, to na każdym kroku możemy odnaleźć koszmary rodem z wizji Gigera. To się ceni. Niestety wiąże się z tym pewien minus - braki w animacji. O ile krajobraz są w stałym ruchu, o tyle akcjom postaci nie towarzyszy żadna animacja. Przykładowo, gdy strażnik na początku ściąga naszyjnik z szyi, ten teleportuje się przed nim i upada na ziemię. Burzy to lekko imersję. Muzyka pasuje do oprawy i nie można jej wiele zarzucić w trakcie rozgrywki. Chociaż nie zrobiła takiego wrażenia, bym chciał ją włączyć w wolnym czasie.

Historia nie jest skomplikowana, ale jest wystarczająco ciekawa, by trzymać gracza przy komputerze do jej ukończenia... o ile przechodzimy grę za pierwszym razem. Gra cierpi na ten sam "problem" co The Walking Dead - przy drugim podejściu (które jest wymagane do osiągnięcia wszystkich osiągnięć) zauważamy, że nasze wybory mają niewielkie znaczenie. Wszystko dlatego, że każdy z nich jest dobry albo zły. Brakowało tutaj niejednoznacznych wyborów, które bardziej angażowałyby gracza. W dodatku (nie licząc zakończenia) mają znaczenie jedynie na to kto da nam jakiś przedmiot. Brakuje alternatywnych zagadek czy rozwiązania problemu. Szkoda, chociaż to niewielka gra indie finansowana na indie go go, więc jest do wybaczenia. Liczę jednak, że w przypadku ewentualnej kontynuacji zostanie to zrobione lepiej.

Wspomnieć należy także o kilku rzeczach, które nie mają wielkiego wpływu na ocenę. Zagadki są proste i można je rozwiązać bez korzystania z dzienniczka. Achievment o niekorzystaniu z dzienniczka zdobyłem za pierwszym podejściem. Nie przeszkadza to jednak za bardzo, może dzięki urozmaiceniu. Żadna z zagadek się nie powtarza. Gra nie należy do długich. Za pierwszym razem na jej ukończenie będziemy potrzebować między trzema a czterema godzinami. Sama mechanika gry zawiera także jedno rozwiązanie, które mnie denerwowalo. Otóż, by zabrać doskonale widoczny kawałek lustra musimy kliknąc na nie, by powiększyć obszar na którym się znajduje, wziąć lustro i cofnąć się do wcześniejszej lokacji. Na szczęście nie występuje to częśto i jest to chyba element powstały na potrzeby Androida/iOS, jednak w przypadku braku animacji rzuca się to w oczy. 

To tyle, gra zdecydowanie warta swojej ceny. Na zachętę dałbym 8/10 i nie jest to specjalnie podciągnięta ocena.

14764221.review:
Tormentum has just made it into my all time point and click adventure favorites list, and I'll try to briefly explain why...

1) The gameplay does not suffer from crazy logic like so many other point and clicks. There is no ridiculous logic like "combine the frog with the book and use it on the bucket to open the chest" that so many other titles are guilty of to create the illusion of complexity. Puzzles here are straightforward yet challenging enough to make you think. In terms of the environment, as long as you are paying attention you won't often find yourself resorting to having to click on everything everywhere to progress. 

2) Unlike many other titles in this genre, there are multiple endings depending on your choices (of which there are many) in game. Replayability!

3) This game is beautiful. The art direction is both moving and disturbing at the same time.  H.R. Geiger comes strongly to mind.

The only drawback to this title is that it will take about 3-4 hours to run through the story once. Subsequent runs will be shorter.

All in all, despite being a little short this title is well worth your money.....especially if you feel drawn to point and click adventures but regularly get put off by some of the tropes of the genre

14760957.review:
Interesująca gra, jednak nie jest warta podawanej przez steam ceny. W samej grze uświadczymy przeżycia emocjonalnego, co mogę zaliczyć na duży plus. Stawiane przed graczem dylematy moralne zmuszają do pewnych refleksji i nie stanowią łatwego wyboru. Zabieg taki został uzyskany dzięki wyeliminowaniu klasycznego podziału na dobro i zło, wszystko jest tutaj malowane w mrocznych barwach, depresyjnych. Tormentum będzie też dobrą grą dla osoby nie mającej częstej styczności z przygodówkami point and click, zagadki należą do prostych i większość wymaganych przedmiotów do użycia w danej lokacji jest umieszczonych w rozsądnej odległości. Częstą przyczyną odbijania się graczy od gier przygodowych są właśnie bardzo abstrakcyjne łamigłówki. Grę ukończyłem w około 2h 30min za pierwszym podejściem. Samo zakończenie natomiast zachęca do ponownej gry by zobaczyć alternatywny wynik naszych poczynań. Na koniec zostawiłem oprawę graficzną i udźwiękowienie. Pierwszy element stoi na mistrzowski poziomie, bardzo dawno nie miałem styczności z tak kapitalnie wykonanymi obrazami będącymi swoistym połączeniem karykatury, turpizmu i abstrakcji. Strona wizualna jest niezwykle sugestywna jednak może się nie spodobać osobą stroniącym od mrocznych klimatów. Muzyka jest bardzo dobra, stonowana melodia podkreślająca klimat rozgrywki. 

Reasumując grę całościowo oceniam bardzo dobrze, liczę również, że dalsze produkcje studia staną się dłuższe i bardziej rozbudowane zarówno w kwestii mechaniki rozgrywki jaki i długości samej przygody. Osoby zainteresowane zachęcam do kupna ale najlepiej w przecenie.

Pragnę również zaznaczyć, że zarzuty z którymi się spotkałem w Internecie na temat omawianej gry co do "braku animacji głównego bohatera" są moim zdaniem absolutnie chybione. Takie gry nie wymagają podobnych animacji i zapobiegają np zasłonięciu przez głównego bohatera jakiegoś ważnego obiektu interaktywnego.

Pozdrawiam i zachęcam do kupna!

14750198.review:
The art is obviously inspired by the paintings of Zbigniew Beksiński (sorry, it does not remind much of H.R. Giger - it is much less phallic for that.) The illustrations are top-notch, contributing greatly to the bleak setting of the game. However, there are barely any animations and the game cuts the scenes to a 3:4 format (leaving you with a black borders on the left and right of your display if it is widescreen.)

As dark as the illustrations is the setting. The corrupted landscape is full of twisted creatures and inhuman machines. It is foul, rotten, broken and crazy. It tries to explain itself in the finale, but even after that I was under the impression that it was grimdark for the sake of trying to be darker and edgier alone. The writing didn't help - you might be able to swallow it straight, but for me the dialogues sounded as written by a goth wannabe.

The game promises moral choices, and the bleak setting gives plenty of opportunities for that. You will be dealing with subjects like imprisonment, torture, murder, deceit and redemption. Unfortunately often the choices fall flat - since everything around you seems like an irrational nightmare there doesn't seem to be much incentive to care either way. However, your choices do influence the development of the story and do carry consequence for that twisted world.

Since you are constantly lost in the mad landscapes I was afraid that I would be similarly lost if the game's puzzles would follow a similar dream logic. However the game makes some effort to explain whys and hows of the crazy inhabitants and the machines littering the environs. It might not exactly make sense, but you should always know what to do. Why is the red ruby, that you snatched from the painting, used in a mechanism opening a door, and why is that mechanism located three floors below said door... that is a completely different question.

The game is rather easy. No puzzles are challenging to begin with, and for most of them there are solutions to be found nearby. There is however a good variety of those tiny logical puzzles, so you are constantly treated to something new. In the end, the game is rather short. The first playthrough took me 3 hours. However, I intend to give it another go to see the results of the other decisions. Replaying it will bring me closer to the advertised 4-6 hours of gameplay.

A solid casual adventure game with dark themes and great illustrations.

As for gameplay, if you're a fan of point-and-click adventures, this doesn't really add anything new to the genre, but it's a solid entry.  The interface is streamlined, with just a single skeletal hand to interact with the environment.  No "look," "use," "speak," etc icons to deal with like in Shadowgate or older Sierra titles.  This is more like the FMV Sierra adventures, like Phantasmagoria.

The puzzles are not particularly difficult.  The few times I found myself stuck, I just left the game for a bit, came back, and found that I had just missed another room or an object on the ground.  A lot of the answers are pretty well spelled out for you.

The story is pretty simplistic, but allows you to make a few choices along the way.  The decisions you make have negligible effects on the gameplay, but will affect the story.

Finally, the game is not very long.  I managed to wrap it up in under 3 hours on my first playthrough, and my second took me about 1 hour.

Tormentum - Dark Sorrow is a beautiful game, and one that is truly worth experiencing, but be warned that it's not particularly difficult, and it's over pretty quickly.

14734743.review:
Awakened behind the twisted metal bars of your cell suspended far above the earth, a magnificently gnarled airship humming ominously above as it carries our mysterious hooded protagonist from their unknown past to a hellish new reality behind the confines of a massive and ghastly prison complex. Will you give in to your new existence of demonic incarceration, or will you find the will to journey into the pits of hell itself and find your freedom?

Tormentum is not a tale for the queasy, with brutal depictions of death, despair, and torture the imagery within is enough to make the average modern horror fan piss their pants in terror. The game comes from a seriously engaging and tasteful angle despite this, and everything is done in a fictionally compelling way that serves the narrative and not just for the sake of shock. The core element in Tormentum is atmosphere, and its surreal influences show to the very root.

The bleak path ahead is riddled with puzzles, mini-games and secrets keeping you just out of reach of your next step to freedom, the next diabolical room of traps and tricks and all forms of unholy devices. Each solution requires a keen eye and generally has the player glossing carefully over each hand-painted environment, which is already a real treat to behold on its own. Paying close attention to small details left across the harrowing stages leads you to discovering artifacts and symbols usually arranged in specific ways to clue you in on how to solve that specific area's solution, and take form as anything from candles being lit in specific order to create a pentagram of light across carefully arranged mirror surfaces to crudely decorated skulls that must be brought back to their rightful tortured remains.

The puzzles here are genuinely fun, as someone who generally hates them I didn't find anything in Tormentum to be tedious or long-winded. They reward those with an appreciation for the remarkable art and encourages enthusiastic exploration of the visuals surrounding the player. With many obstacles come moral choices, and many of the solutions face the player with painful decisions that weigh on your mind throughout, the betrayal of friends and murders of the seemingly innocent bringing you closer to your goal but further from humanity. The spirit of classic point and click adventure gaming is present, and you'll be completing plenty of satisfyingly simple and rewarding tasks and pushing for that next gruesome screen of beautifully detailed scenery though never without consequence.

The artwork itself is absolutely breathtaking not because it is pretty, gorgeous, or inspiring but because it is fantastically grotesque in detail. Every organic curve, every sickeningly moist surface of glistening quality and every rusted jag of blackened metal stand out with each transition of a scene, each one more jaw-dropping than the last. A brutal assault of rapid images portraying ruthlessly grim imagery, making escape the one bright glimmer of hope in our protagonist's peril. There's an unmistakable similarity to some of the most macabre and surreal artists from the organically twisted curves of Giger to the grand hellscapes of Bosch, combined with the likes of what could be straight out of a Dimmu Borgir album cover just for extra measure. And it isn't just the art; I've already caught several references to works of the surreal including the phrase "Fire Walk with Me", showing that these brilliantly demented creators have their influences set in the right place.

It's not just from these decadent and long renown artists that Tormentum draws its artistic influences from however, there are plenty of modern day touches that gamers and horror enthusiasts of every ilk will reminisce on from darkened knights dressed in twisted sets of armor akin to the foes in the Dark Souls series, to the natural feeling animations of Odin Sphere that move fluidly with every rising breath of a character or rusted movement of the cold metal environment around you. Tormentum has the makings of a classic, and if you aren't turned away by it's cruel imagery this is one fucked up trip worth taking.

14733854.review:
Категория point-and-click квестов в Стиме невелика, но свою долю верных поклонников имеет. Tormentum - Dark Sorrow может привлечь аудиторию со стороны благодаря тому, что делает ставку на выразительный стиль и отсутствие казуальных мини-игр по поиску спрятанных предметов, которые просочились, кажется, уже всюду.
   Конечно, огромную роль в этой импульсивной покупке сыграли скриншоты, а также признания авторов, что вдохновение они черпали из работ Гигера и From Software. Графически мир Tormentum получился действительно мрачным и беспощадным, и музыкальное сопровождение ему под стать. 
   Любовь к своему детищу - в каждом кадре. Это не может не подкупать.

   Нашего героя (разумеется, лишенного памяти о предшествующих событиях) бросают в одну из камер замка; рыцарь-страж в рогатом шлеме обещает скорые "очистительные" пытки и скрывается из виду. Так что первая задача - выбраться из заключения, а затем изучить это место и, возможно, предотвратить нечто ужасное.
   Загадки в целом стандартные для жанра, опирающиеся на сбор ключевых вещей и решение локальных паззлов. Тут и там герой, естественно, в весьма неуклюжей манере будет давать прозрачные комментарии, касающиеся связи объектов, а на важных точках начнут мерцать привлекающие внимание огоньки, так что заблудиться сложно. Блокнот с подсказками работает на всех экранах, инвентарь ненавязчив и редко заполняется более чем на пять-шесть предметов.
   Но интересны те выборы, которые предоставляются по ходу игры. Продвижение по сюжету возможно несколькими путями, и выборы позволяют привнести в квест элементы самого настоящего отыгрыша. Решите проявлять милосердие или безжалостно расправитесь с менее удачливыми пленниками? Сыграете в дружбу или пойдете вперед по трупам? Это уже тянет на два прохождения, ачивки прилагаются.

   Минусов немного, поэтому о них в конце.
   Из-за своеобразного подхода к перспективе, призванного оживить статичную картинку, стены иногда двигаются отдельно от пола. Плюс чума жанра: ключи и рычаги все еще находятся в подозрительно удобных местах, редкие загадки требуют компоненты хотя бы из трех экранов, и собирательство подчас вообще не имеет за собой никаких оснований ("А возьму-ка я с собой этот череп, он явно может пригодиться мне в замке, полном сотни других черепов!") 
   Экспозиция излагается столь возвышенным слогом, что место ей - где-нибудь в театре или на Шекспировских чтениях. Отчасти это вина русского текста, в английском варианте все намного менее натянуто; что не оправдывает стражей, которые запросто выдают сбежавшему пленнику схему работы различных механизмов в замке. Если бы только авторы переняли и скупой стиль повествования Demon's Souls, а не только его визуальный дизайн...
   Но довольно нытья. В остальном - игра выше всяких похвал, и даже если квесты не вызывают в вас никаких ностальгических воспоминаний, на Tormentum стоит взглянуть. Хотя бы - да, я готова сказать это - ради графена.

14733687.review:
Tormentum - Dark Sorrow is a point and click adventure thrown into a damnable orgy of suffering, misery and despair in the visual trappings of Giger and Beksinski.  The art is easily the linchpin of this release, those richly hellish and tortuous scenes are so morbidly captivating and visceral that one has to question the mental health of the artist. It’s not just those wide panoramic vistas that give off a sense of infernal grandeur, it’s also the attention to detail in small objects, items obscured and a wealth of visually suggestive scenery and object placement that make the art direction and presentation so incredible. Feed into that the bleak and austere soundtrack and you have an audio visual phenomenon. 
Gameplay is your standard point and click adventure types, you are to find items that they may resolve other problems that hinder your progress in the game, rinse and repeat. To this end the game employs a great number of puzzles which are fairly enjoyable and not too taxing, oftentimes clues given to you on how to solve them are found in other locations. Overall the gameplay is simple and for the most part is secondary to the experience, not so much in the sense it has been neglected, but more so that it is a means to an end rather than the core of the experience. 
The lore and story are slowly bled out to you, never providing you with too much detail, but just enough dark particulars to provide a minimalist context allowing your imagination to run wild and give a few grains of morality in weighing up your actions. NPC’s are often times minimalist in interaction, but are quite capable of reinforcing the central themes to the game and giving it greater depth. This overall vagueness reinforces the crushing sense of despair and disorientation that accompanies you in the game throughout. 
At certain points in the game you are presented with choices and whilst at face value they are your standard black and white good or bad dichotomy, the lack of guidance or understanding of your role in this world brings your own philosophical dilemmas into the fray. Can one kill for freedom? Is it a crime to punish the wicked? Is it my place to judge them so? Am I being lied to? Etc.  
Gameplay is short, I would guess perhaps around 5 hours in total, but what an intense and rewarding 5 hours they are! Not forgetting that there is some replayability in making alternate choices in the game. However playtime is irrelevant, playing Tormentum is an experience more than a game, a quasi-philosophical interactive grotesquery of redemption and punishment set in the most horrific and stunning abysses.

I'm on the fence about [i]Tormentum: Dark Sorrow[/i]. I did like it somewhat, and I am starved for good Dark Fantasy games and good Point & Click games. But I've settled on a negative review to counterbalance some of the glowing ones, for three main reasons.

First, it's just not a very solid Point & Click. Puzzles are simplistic, and the game holds your hand a lot. Example: IIRC there is [i]one[/i] puzzle that requires combining items, and there are instructions written on the wall (literally) for how to combine them. Puzzles are the core mechanic, but I rarely felt puzzled. As a result, progress was unrewarding.

Second, it's just not a very good Dark Fantasy world: put this grotesque character in that bizarre setting, and hey-presto, that's a scene. But underneath the visually disturbing imagery, I still wanted a coherent [i]world[/i], and I didn't find it. The world seems to have been built around the available art, not the other way around. This becomes abundantly clear in the Third Act (where there's 100+ "paintings" lying around that are irrelevant for the story, and do nothing to build the world) and during the credits (where a trove of art is displayed that shows characters, scenes, and worlds that the player has never encountered once during the game, and which seem to be completely unconnected to the game). Now, the art is all great, don't get me wrong: but I wasn't aiming to buy an interactive artbook from someone's "Giger/Beksinski phase." The devs seem to be aware of this disconencted feeling of the world, and the game actually attempts to explain it away [spoiler]by claiming at the end that the world is composed of your confused memories,[/spoiler] but this struck me as weak.

Third, the ending was a muffled fart of moralizing that really undid a lot of the Dark atmosphere I'd been hoping for in the game.

[h1]Золотое правило нравственности[/h1]

[quote=Иммануил Кант]"Поступай так, чтобы ты всегда относился к человечеству и в своем лице, и в лице всякого другого также как к цели и никогда не относился бы к нему только как к средству"[/quote]


Tormentum - с первого взгляда привлекает внимание своим мрачным, гротескным, но при этом очень стильным артом и саундтреком. Цитата Канта в самом начале игры очень к ней подходит, поскольку по ходу действия не раз приходится задумываться о морали своих поступков и их последствиях. Кто главный герой? 40141114.review:
In one sentence: Tormentum is a gorgeous hidden object puzzle game...for people that don't play hidden object puzzle games, without the hidden object puzzles, and with a Giger reskin and nice music.

I recommend this game for the art and the soundtrack, but not much else. If you like neoclassical music (I don't know where people are getting the idea this has a metal/nu-metal soundtrack, but you can go online and see that the music is usually either neoclassical or industrial) and art inspired by H.R. Giger, you'll like this game.

I'm giving this game a positive review because of the atmospheric elements. It's only $12 as of this review, and I think that's a fair price given how short it is. I'm willing to give short games good reviews if they're basically interactive art books, and arguably, that's what Tormentum is.

It's really short. I think it took me an hour or two to finish the first time around. However, I do play a lot of games like this.

The puzzles aren't that hard. It's a point and click adventure, but various puzzles feel like the same puzzles you'd find in an Artifex Mundi game, just skinned with Gigeresque graphics. e.g. "it's a gear puzzle, but the gears are rusty!", "it's a mirror puzzle, but the mirrors are around a Gothic statue!" Puzzles didn't feel particularly inspired and none of them were puzzles that I hadn't played before in other games.

This honestly felt like an Artifex Mundi game but without the hidden object puzzle parts, like an Artifex Mundi HOPA but for a different demographic. Most of the puzzles are find item, use item in another room, get item, rinse, repeat. Sometimes, using the item triggers a puzzle you need to solve to get another item or to advance the plot. That's basically it.

I don't know if this game counts as a "Choices Matter" game. There are choices in the game, but all they affect is the ending. In my opinion, "Choices Matter" usually has to do with things mattering during the actual game. If you have to pick between eating one of 3 apples (random example) during a game, and that influences getting ending 1, 2, or 3, but otherwise, has nothing to do with gameplay, that isn't really a case of choices mattering. The morality system also seems very arbitrary regarding what counts as "good" vs. what counts as "evil" given there's ways to justify any choice as good, and any choice as evil.

People online have some issues with the ending. [spoiler]Namely, the ending expresses opinions about suicide.[/spoiler] If you are fine with that and, like me, don't care much about the message of a video game and can appreciate a game without agreeing with it, you'll probably be fine, but that's a decision for you to make.

There isn't much replay value, but for games of this genre, there tends not to be. There's 2-3 endings (depending on what you count as an ending) and after your first play through, you can probably blast through this game in 15-30 minutes.

40091614.review:
[i]"TORMENTUM is a dark Point & Click adventure game.The dreamlike, nightmarish atmosphere of the game was inspired by works of painters [b]H.R. Giger[/b] and [b]Zdzislaw Beksinski.[/b] The game's final look and feel was also strongly influenced by the universes of games such as Demon's Souls or Dark Seed"[/i]

The mechanics are of course what you might expect from a genre so aptly identified by its name--and the game does not disappoint there---but it's really the crazy style and atmosphere that will drive you forward. The influences shout their names loudly with such magnificent and ominous artwork. While their presence stands prominent and clear, they never overshadow the emergent style so as to render it merely derivative.. The familiar atmosphere lends well to their melted execution and brings to life an environment uniquely defined from the games surrounding it.

I'd absolutely love for more "point and click" games to go balls to the wall with their themes and all those stylistic elements that are just so ripe for change and interpretation atop the genre's skeletal mechanics. Whether its more "dark fantasy" or something else, there's such potential in experimentation and an untapped craving for these loud, boisterous settings and premises unlike the genre has seen before.
